## What is Online Proctoring?
Online proctoring refers to the process of supervising candidates remotely during online assessments to ensure fairness and prevent cheating.
Traditionally, human invigilators monitored exams physically. But with Xobinâ€™s AIdriven proctoring, most of the supervision is automated. This means realtime detection of suspicious behavior, multiple devices, or unauthorized actions without intruding on the candidateâ€™s privacy.
Whether youâ€™re an HR leader, recruiter, or educator, Xobinâ€™s proctoring suite guarantees the security and integrity of every online test.

## Why Xobinâ€™s AI Proctoring Stands Out
Unlike conventional monitoring tools, Xobinâ€™s proctoring solution offers a multilayered security approach. It integrates AI algorithms, realtime analytics, and customizable controls, allowing organizations to create the perfect balance between strict invigilation and candidate comfort.
Hereâ€™s how Xobin helps you conduct cheatproof assessments with AIpowered precision.

## Key Xobin AI Proctoring Features that Prevent Cheating

## Question Shuffle and Randomization
Every test session is unique. Xobin automatically randomizes question order and answer options, making it impossible for candidates to predict or share exact sequences. This eliminates collusion and guarantees fairness across multiple test sessions.
To prevent plagiarism and information sharing, Xobin blocks all cut, copy, and paste operations, including keyboard shortcuts. This ensures that candidates canâ€™t copy questions or search for answers externally.
Rightclick menus are completely disabled during tests, ensuring candidates canâ€™t use browser developer tools, inspect elements or open any unauthorized windows.

## Keystroke Recording in Coding Tests
For coding assessments , Xobin records every keystroke to identify a candidateâ€™s unique typing pattern. This allows evaluators to verify code originality and detect any external code import.
Xobinâ€™s webcam proctoring utilizes the builtin microphone and camera functionalities to capture continuous video or periodic snapshots throughout the test. This ensures monitoring realtime behavior of candidates without interrupting the test experience.
Xobinâ€™s offtab activity tracking feature monitors testtakerâ€™s behavior to detect any attempt to navigate away from the assessment window. If a candidate attempts to switch tabs or access other applications during the assessment, the system immediately flags any offtab activity and they are promptly warned about the violation of exam rules.
Persistent disregard for warnings may result in disqualification from the exam.

## PS: Warnings are given to candidates.
Using advanced motion analysis, Xobin detects when a candidate leaves their seat or moves out of frame, alerting proctors immediately. This ensures the candidate remains present and attentive during the assessment.
Our system identifies simultaneous device usage, such as smartphones or secondary monitors. Even partially visible devices are detected and flagged, ensuring no external resources are used during the assessment. This feature ensures the assessment remains devicelocked and secure.
The AI proctoring system identifies if more than one person appears in the camera frame. This feature assists HR teams in verifying that the right candidate is genuinely attempting the assessment without external assistance.

## Screen Recording & Browser Activity Monitoring
Xobin records the entire screen session, capturing every movement and browser tab opened. All browser tabs, window switches, and navigations are tracked in real time. Any attempt to visit external pages or open new windows is instantly flagged.
Using advanced eyetracking technology, Xobin monitors gaze direction to detect if the candidate frequently looks away from the screen, a common indicator of external help. Frequent offscreen gazes trigger realtime alerts for potential misconduct.

## Audio Recording & RealTime Analysis
Through microphone access, Xobin captures and analyzes background noise, detecting conversations or other forms of unauthorized help. Every sound event is analyzed in realtime by AI for accurate flagging.
Xobin offers a secure browser environment that blocks all external applications, popups, and unauthorized access. It restricts 90% of external app access, creating a closed and distractionfree environment.
Xobin also offers live human proctoring for added security. Trained proctors oversee small candidate batches, ensuring no suspicious behavior goes unnoticed.
Xobin scans codes or subjective answers of candidates to detect plagiarism or duplicate content. Detailed proctoring reports help recruiters identify originality of assessment and candidate integrity.
These are custombuilt questions which can not be searched on the web, require critical thinking and personal interpretation to answer the question.

## AI Trust Score Algorithm
At the end of each test, Xobinâ€™s Trust Score evaluates a candidateâ€™s overall integrity based on multiple proctoring signals. This helps recruiters instantly identify which candidates took the test honestly and which ones might require review.

plain_text:
Website: https://www.adaface.com/xobinalternatives/

## Top Sections: integrations, about, platform

## Page 1/10: Top 10 Xobin Alternatives & Competitors

## Top 10 Xobin Alternatives & Competitors
Choosing the right assessment platform is like picking the perfect tool for a job â€“ you want something that fits your needs just right. Xobin is a popular choice, but it's not the only fish in the sea when it comes to evaluating talent. Maybe you are looking for custom questions or language tests or better proctoring; you need to explore other options. In this guide, we will explore ten alternatives and competitors to Xobin to help you make an informed decision.
Before we dive deep, hereâ€™s a quick glance at the alternatives we'll be discussing:
â€¢ Adaface: For evaluating candidates across a wide range of skills with a focus on question quality. Extensive 500+ skill test library covering Cognitive, Business, Finance, Typing, Languages, Rolespecific and IT tests.
â€¢ iMocha: Use for skills assessment and candidate analytics.
â€¢ Talview: Use when you need an endtoend digital recruiting platform.
â€¢ Coderbyte: Use for assessing coding skills with challenges and projects.
â€¢ Pymetrics: Use when you need gamebased assessments for personality and cognitive traits.
â€¢ Alva Labs: Use when you need personality and logic assessments.
â€¢ Glider AI: Use when you need AIpowered talent screening and matching.
â€¢ Testgrid: Use when you need online assessments and remote proctoring.
â€¢ Humantelligence: Use when you need behavioral assessments and team analytics.
â€¢ Bizneo HR: Use when you need a full HR suite with assessment capabilities.
Adaface stands out with its focus on highquality, nongoogleable questions, a wide test library covering aptitude, finance, personality, and technical roles, and a strong proctoring suite. It's a great option if you want assessments that are both accurate and candidatefriendly.
With clients in 70+ countries, Adaface offers a variety of tests, including aptitude tests , finance tests , personality tests , and assessments for technical and coding roles .

## Explore this post with:
What prompts hiring teams to explore alternatives to Xobin?
I've dug deep to uncover why HR professionals, recruiters, and hiring managers are actively seeking alternatives to Xobin. Here's what I discovered.
Limited Options for Customization. While Xobin offers a library of prebuilt tests, teams might find themselves wanting more control. The ability to tailor questions to reflect a company's specific needs, industry nuances, or unique role requirements can be a gamechanger for accurate candidate evaluation. Some companies want to add their own questions as well and Xobin doesn't offer this.
Lack of Focus on Candidate Experience. Let's face it: traditional assessments can feel like a chore. Candidates appreciate a more engaging and userfriendly experience. Solutions that offer features like mobile accessibility and clear support documentation can significantly improve candidate completion rates and overall perception of your company.
Pricing Transparency. Many appreciate knowing what they are paying upfront and having multiple plans to choose from depending on their team size. With Xobin, there's no free trial and you need to book a demo to see pricing. This might be a hurdle for some companies.
Navigating the world of assessment platforms can feel like a maze. Let's cut to the chase with a quick comparison of Xobin and its alternatives, helping you find the perfect fit for your hiring needs.

## Tests for 500+ skills

## Annual creditbased plans with no seat restrictions

## Subscription based pricing model

## Varied plans for different needs

## Coding challenges and courses

## Subscription based pricing plans

## Custom pricing, contact for quote

## Contact them for pricing details

## Automated assessment workflows
Best for: Skillsbased hiring assessments for both technical and nontechnical roles.
While Xobin offers a range of assessments, companies seeking a more versatile and candidatefriendly solution should consider Adaface as a strong alternative.
One common concern with Xobin is the lack of transparency around pricing and the absence of a free trial. This can make it difficult for businesses to evaluate the platform's suitability before committing financially. Adaface addresses this by offering a free trial with sample tests and full access to proctoring features, ensuring a riskfree evaluation experience.
Adaface shines with its commitment to candidate experience, strong proctoring, and a wide test library. Some key highlights include:
â€¢ A test library covering 500+ skills across various domains
â€¢ Strong support for aptitude, finance, personality, and business roles

## â€¢ Robust proctoring suite to ensure test integrity
â€¢ Focus on company branding to create a seamless candidate experience

## â€¢ Detailed scorecards for informed decisionmaking
â€¢ Pricing that includes all proctoring features, without seatbased charges
Adaface emphasizes company branding, enabling you to customize the assessment experience with your logo and brand colors. This creates a seamless and familiar experience for candidates, increasing engagement and reinforcing your brand identity.
Customizable invitation, shortlist, and rejection templates further extend your brand messaging, ensuring consistency across all candidate communications. A branded assessment experience demonstrates your commitment to candidate experience and enhances your employer brand.
Adaface's proctoring features are designed to maintain the integrity of your assessments. These include webcam proctoring, which monitors candidates during the test, and window/tab proctoring, which detects if candidates navigate away from the test window.
Additional measures like IP address tracking, device fingerprinting, and copypaste protection further deter cheating. Adaface also has built in Chat GPT protection. These features provide recruiters with the confidence that the assessment results accurately reflect a candidate's abilities.

## Adaface vs Xobin Attributes
â€¢ More than 500 skills tests on technical skills, cognitive abilities, language proficiency, and more
â€¢ ExtensiveATS integrationsand the possibility to build custom integrations

## â€¢ Excellent anticheating measures

## â€¢ Unlimited team seats in all plans

## â€¢ Tests available in multiple languages

## â€¢ Regular updates and quality checks on tests

## â€¢ No live video interviews

## â€¢ No takehome assignment support
Adaface offers transparent and flexible pricing plans to suit various hiring needs. A free trial is available, providing access to sample tests and all proctoring features. Paid plans include Individual ($180/yr), Starter ($500/yr), Pro ($900/yr), Scale ($3000/yr), Growth ($5500/yr), Enterprise ($20,000/yr), and Unlimited ($50,000/yr). All pricing plans cover all proctoring features and 500+ tests.

## Best for: Skills intelligence for workforce
iMocha offers skill assessments alongside skill intelligence to help companies understand their workforce's current skills. They also help plan for future needs, and address skill gaps through hiring. Sounds pretty neat, right?
Unlike Xobin, iMocha doesn't let you create custom questions. While they do offer readytouse tests, the inability to tailor assessments to your specific needs can be a real bummer. Imagine not being able to quiz candidates on that super specific skill you need!
On the other hand, if you're looking for a platform that lets you add your own questions and even designs custom tests based on job descriptions, then Adaface is the way to go.

## How iMocha compares to Xobin?

## â€¢ AIpowered skill gap analysis

## â€¢ Candidate skills and certification filter

## â€¢ Live coding interview platform

## â€¢ Large skills assessment library.

## â€¢ Provides skill benchmarking reports.
â€¢ Supports proctoring features like webcam and window violation.

## â€¢ Offers coding assessments with code playback.

## â€¢ Integrates with multiple ATS platforms.

## â€¢ Doesn't allow creation of custom questions.

## â€¢ Lacks custom data location support for security.

## â€¢ No custom API available.
â€¢ Questions are easily googleable or answered using GPT, making it difficult to assess candidates accurately.
iMocha doesn't offer transparent pricing. You'll need to contact them for a custom quote. They also do not offer a free trial, so you would need to take their word for it on the quality of the assessments.

## Best for: Video interview and assessments
Talview provides a platform that combines video interviewing with skills assessments. It aims to streamline the hiring process by integrating these features into a single platform.
Unlike Xobin, Talview leverages video interviews more heavily, integrating them directly with assessments. This allows for a more indepth evaluation of candidates, combining technical skills with communication and soft skills. This helps recruiters see the whole picture.
Talview offers a range of assessments, including aptitude, behavioral, and coding tests. However, it lacks the option for creating customized tests per job description , a feature offered by Adaface .

## How TalView compares to Xobin?
â€¢ Live Coding Interviews: Provides an IDE for realtime coding assessments.
â€¢ Video Interviewing: Integrates video technology for asynchronous and live interviews.
â€¢ Assessment Library: Offers a range of prebuilt tests for various skills.
â€¢ AIpowered Talent Insights: Uses AI to analyze candidate data and provide insights.
â€¢ Remote Proctoring: Includes features like screen sharing monitoring and browser lock.
â€¢ Automation: Automates various stages of the hiring process like interview scheduling.
â€¢ Candidate Experience: Focuses on providing a userfriendly experience for candidates.

## â€¢ API Integrations: Integrates with multiple ATS systems.
â€¢ Limited Test Customization: Does not support full customization of tests based on job descriptions.
â€¢ No Typing Tests: Lacks support for typing tests.
â€¢ Missing some Proctoring Features: Doesn't offer device fingerprint or IP proctoring for advanced cheat detection.
â€¢ No Free Trial: No option to explore the platform before committing to a paid plan.
Talview does not publicly display its pricing details. Interested users need to fill out a form on their website to request a demo and receive pricing information. This lack of transparency makes it harder to gauge the fit for smaller businesses or those looking for quick, selfservice options.

## Best for: Technical skill challenges platform
Coderbyte is all about sharpening those coding skills. They provide challenges to help developers level up. It's like a digital dojo for programmers, offering coding challenges and courses to refine skills.
Unlike Xobin, which offers a broader range of assessments, Coderbyte laserfocuses on technical skills. This specialization can be a boon if you're only looking to assess coding abilities. It's a platform built by developers, for developers, aiming to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application.
However, this focus also means Coderbyte lacks the versatility to assess other crucial skills like aptitude, personality, or business acumen. If your hiring process demands a more rounded view of candidates, you might need to supplement Coderbyte with other tools. For companies seeking a broad range of assessments, including personality tests and aptitude tests , a platform like Adaface is definitely worth considering.

## How Coderbyte compares to Xobin?

## â€¢ Coding challenges in multiple languages

## â€¢ Skillbased assessment reports

## â€¢ Custom coding questions

## â€¢ Large community and extensive challenge library.

â€¢ Doesn't offer features like video interviewing or custom branding.
Coderbyte offers several pricing plans, including a free trial. The basic plan starts at $199 per month. They also have a subscription plan for $1,699 per year and pay as you go plans. Contact them for enterprise pricing.

## Best for: Biasfree Talent Discovery Solution
Pymetrics offers a unique approach to talent assessment. Instead of traditional resumes and skills tests, it uses gamified assessments based on neuroscience to evaluate candidates' cognitive and personality traits. The goal? To predict job performance and potential, while reducing bias in the hiring process.
Pymetrics shines where traditional assessments fall short, especially in earlystage screening. While Xobin offers a broader range of skillsbased assessments, Pymetrics focuses on innate qualities and potential, valuable for identifying candidates who might not have the exact skills but possess the aptitude to learn and excel.
However, if you need to assess specific skills like coding or accounting, Pymetrics might not be the best fit. It's more about predicting potential than measuring current expertise. For indepth skills assessment, platforms like Adaface offer a more direct and targeted approach.

## How Pymetrics compares to Xobin?
â€¢ Gamified Assessments: Candidates play a series of games designed to measure cognitive and emotional traits.
â€¢ AIDriven Matching: Pymetrics uses AI to match candidates to roles based on their assessment results.
â€¢ Bias Mitigation: The platform aims to reduce bias by focusing on inherent traits rather than experience.

## â€¢ Focuses on potential, not just experience.

## â€¢ Aims to reduce bias in hiring decisions.

## â€¢ Can uncover hidden talents and aptitudes.

## â€¢ Offers a unique and engaging candidate experience.

â€¢ Lacks customization options for creating tailored assessments.
Pymetrics does not publicly display its pricing. You'll need to contact their sales team to discuss your specific needs and receive a custom quote. This lack of transparency can be a drawback for companies looking for quick and easy pricing comparisons. Be prepared to engage in a sales process to understand the costs involved.

## Best for: Tech hiring assessments quickly
Alva Labs is a platform focused on skills and personality assessments, primarily catering to tech roles. They offer a suite of tests designed to evaluate candidates on coding skills, cognitive abilities, and personality traits.
Alva Labs shines when you need to quickly gauge a candidate's coding skills or understand their personality profile within a tech context. Xobin offers a broader range of assessments, Alva Labs zeroes in on the tech sector.
However, Alva Labs doesn't offer the flexibility of custom questions or tailored assessments based on the job description, unlike Adaface's skill assessment platform . While Alva Labs offers readytouse tests, it doesn't give you the power to create assessments specific to your unique needs.

Glider AI specializes in assessing technical skills, but it might fall short if you need to evaluate business acumen or rolespecific competencies beyond tech. Xobin, on the other hand, covers a broader spectrum of skills, including business and aptitude.

TestGrid offers a platform designed to assess candidates, focusing primarily on aptitude tests. While Xobin covers a broader range of skills, including coding and jobspecific assessments, TestGrid centers its efforts on evaluating a candidate's aptitude and personality.

## Adaface vs. Xobin: Detailed InDepth Comparison
Recruiters need preemployment screening to ensure they find the best candidates quickly. It helps verify skills and reduces the chances of hiring the wrong person.
This blog post will guide you through the differences between Adaface and Xobin. You'll learn what each platform offers and why Adaface might be the better choice for your hiring needs .

## How does Adaface work?
Adaface is a preemployment testing platform that helps companies of all sizes screen candidates with customized assessments. These assessments are designed to be engaging and conversational, unlike the typical tests that feel like an exam.
Recruiters use Adaface to evaluate candidates across various roles, from software developers to sales professionals. With a mix of scenariobased MCQs and coding questions, Adaface provides a nuanced view of a candidate's skill set.
Another key feature is the ability to create custom assessments tailored to specific job descriptions. This ensures that the tests are closely aligned with the requirements of the role, leading to more accurate candidate evaluations.
Adaface also offers remote proctoring features , which help maintain test integrity. Features like browser and webcam monitoring, along with customized test questions , enhance the reliability of the assessments.

## How does Xobin work?
Xobin is a preemployment screening platform providing a wide range of assessments designed to evaluate various candidate skills.
The platform offers programming tests, situational judgment tests, aptitude tests, business skills, typing tests, personality tests, and more. A typical use case includes evaluating a candidate for technical roles through a combination of coding questions and situational judgment assessments.
Xobin's strengths lie in its broad test offerings. It supports a variety of assessments like aptitude tests and personality tests, providing a wellrounded view of a candidate's capabilities.
However, Xobin lacks language tests and doesn't support artificial intelligence assessments, limiting its scope for roles requiring language proficiency or AI expertise.

## Adaface vs Xobin: Test libraries
Adaface offers a vast and diverse test library that caters to multiple industries and job roles, including programming, finance, cognitive ability, and more. Meanwhile, Xobin also provides a comprehensive range of tests covering various domains such as business, finance, and cloud technologies.
Using these test libraries allows recruiters to evaluate a wide array of skills and competencies, ensuring a better match for job roles and reducing the likelihood of hiring mismatches.
The Adaface test library includes over 500 preemployment assessment tests for different skills , which are fully customizable to suit specific hiring needs. Available tests range across various disciplines, such as programming , rolespecific , personality , language , and cognitive ability .
Recruiters leverage the Adaface test library to assess candidates for various roles from technical positions to customer service and marketing. The tests help in identifying the right talent by focusing on not just technical skills but also personality and cognitive abilities.
One of the distinct advantages of the Adaface library is its adaptability to create customized questions and unique assessments tailored to job descriptions. This ensures that every test matches the specific requirements of the role, helping recruiters make wellinformed hiring decisions based on datadriven insights.
Xobin's test library covers a wide range of assessments, including programming, situational judgment, aptitude, business, typing, personality, finance, and cloud tests. They offer readytouse tests and allow users to add their own questions.
Employers can benefit from Xobin's diverse array of tests to evaluate candidates for various roles, from technical positions to businessoriented jobs. The platform helps streamline the recruitment process by offering a comprehensive selection of prebuilt assessments.
However, Xobin doesn't provide language or AI tests, and lacks customization features such as creating custom questions or tailored tests based on specific job descriptions. This might limit their usability for certain recruiting needs.

This makes it easy for small teams to manage their candidate outreach effectively and establish a smooth hiring process. For more insights on optimizing your hiring strategy, check out our guide on How to Select an Assessment/Coding Test Solution .

## Xobin's enterprise and startup friendliness
Xobin offers a range of features designed for both enterprises and startups, including ATS integrations and GDPR compliance. They support rolebased access to accommodate different user needs within organizations. However, they lack a custom API and unlimited team seats that could benefit larger teams.
For instance, startups can leverage Xobin's ATS integrations to streamline their hiring processes without leaving their existing HR systems. Enterprises can take advantage of the rolebased access to ensure that sensitive data is only available to the right team members.
Yet, while Xobin provides multiple question sets, they miss out on offering bulk actions and customization options that can significantly enhance the efficiency of mass hiring events. This could be a game changer for companies looking to scale their recruitment efforts.

## Comparison of enterprise and startup friendliness

## Adaface vs Xobin: Customer support
Customer support is the unsung hero of assessment platforms, playing a key role in ensuring recruiters can navigate features smoothly and resolve issues quickly. A good support system can make all the difference in a highpressure hiring environment.

## Adaface's customer support features
Adaface offers a variety of support options, including live chat and email, so you can get your questions answered without missing a beat. Additionally, there's a detailed help center filled with resources and howto guides for common queries.
For those in enterprise plans, dedicated priority support provides a direct line to customer success contacts, ensuring that your specific needs are addressed promptly. This means youâ€™re never left in the dark if something goes awry during your hiring process.
Recruiters can also benefit from personalized training and onboarding sessions with Adaface, helping them maximize platform features right from the start. Get started with our Adaface product tour for a visual walkthrough and see how these support options can enhance your hiring experience.

## Xobin's customer support features
Xobin offers email support, live chat, and a help center for its users. These features ensure that customers can get timely assistance and access to frequently asked questions.
It remains unclear if Xobin provides dedicated priority support or training and onboarding services. Additionally, phone assistance is not available.

## Comparison of customer support

## Adaface vs Xobin: Final verdict
Both Adaface and Xobin offer features like programming tests , situational judgment tests, and business tests. They cover a wide range of skills important for various roles.
Even though both platforms seem similar, Adaface stands out by providing a conversational interface, which enhances the candidate experience. Adaface also supports multiple languages, making it versatile for global recruitment.
Xobin lacks key features such as AI tests and custom tests per job description. These elements are crucial when you need a tailored assessment to accurately gauge a candidate's fit.

## Streamline hiring with skill tests
Adaface includes these missing features, offering AI tests and designing custom tests based on job descriptions . This ensures a more precise assessment, saving recruiters time and effort.
Preemployment assessments help recruiters make informed decisions. They offer tests on various skills, ensuring candidates meet the job requirements.
Using these assessments, recruiters can streamline their hiring process, reducing bias and focusing on skills rather than resumes. This leads to better hiring outcomes and a stronger workforce.
Adaface is your goto solution for preemployment assessments. With features like custom tests and a conversational interface, it outshines competitors. Check out our plans or read more about how to choose the right assessment tool .

Page 4/10: The Science Behind Aptitude Tests: What Employers Are Really Measuring
Aptitude tests have become a routine part of recruitment processes across many industries. Yet for candidates, they often remain poorly understood. Results can feel abstract, and the reasoning behind their use is not always clearly explained. When complex thinking skills are reduced to numerical scores, it is natural to question what those scores actually represent.
To understand aptitude testing, it is helpful to look beyond individual questions and consider the scientific principles that underpin these assessments. Doing so provides candidates with a clearer picture of what employers are evaluating and how aptitude tests are intended to inform hiring decisions.
What Are Aptitude Tests?
Aptitude tests are standardized assessments designed to evaluate how individuals process information, reason through unfamiliar problems, and reach conclusions under time pressure. Unlike knowledge-based exams, which measure what a person has learned, aptitude tests focus on cognitive processes and problem-solving ability.
This distinction explains their widespread use in recruitment. Employers rely on aptitude tests to compare candidates from different educational backgrounds, work histories, and cultural contexts using a consistent and objective framework.
Cognitive Ability as the Foundation
Most aptitude tests are grounded in research on general cognitive ability, often referred to in psychology as g . This construct reflects a broad capacity for reasoning, learning, and problem-solving. Extensive research over many decades has shown that cognitive ability is one of the strongest predictors of job performance, particularly in roles that involve complexity, analysis, and ongoing learning.
Cognitive ability is not a single skill. It is a combination of interrelated mental functions, including logical reasoning, pattern recognition, working memory, processing speed, and verbal and numerical comprehension. Aptitude tests are designed to observe how these abilities interact when candidates are faced with tasks they have not encountered before.
The Abilities Employers Are Assessing
Although aptitude tests differ in format and emphasis, most fall into a small number of established categories. Each category focuses on specific aspects of cognitive functioning that are relevant to workplace performance.
Numerical reasoning tests assess how effectively candidates interpret quantitative information and identify relationships between figures. Employers use these tests to evaluate skills relevant to data analysis, financial decision-making, forecasting, and performance monitoring.
These assessments are not intended to test advanced mathematics. Instead, they focus on logical interpretation, accuracy, and the ability to work with numbers efficiently under time pressure.
Verbal reasoning tests measure how well candidates understand written information, identify key points, and evaluate arguments. These skills are essential in roles that involve communication, documentation, policy interpretation, or decision-making based on written material.
Strong performance in verbal reasoning suggests that a candidate can process complex texts accurately and draw sound conclusions from them.
Abstract and Non-Verbal Reasoning
Abstract or non-verbal reasoning tests use shapes, patterns, and visual sequences to assess problem-solving ability without relying on language or numerical knowledge. Because they are less dependent on education and language proficiency, they are often used to reduce cultural or educational bias in early screening stages.
Employers value these tests for roles that require adaptability, strategic thinking, and the ability to recognize structure and logic in unfamiliar situations.
Mechanical and Technical Reasoning
Mechanical reasoning tests assess understanding of basic physical principles such as force, motion, leverage, and mechanical interaction. They are commonly used for technical, engineering, and operational roles.
Performance on these tests provides insight into how quickly a candidate can understand practical systems and apply logical reasoning to physical processes.
Why Employers Use Aptitude Tests
From an employerâ€™s perspective, aptitude tests serve several important purposes. Cognitive ability has strong predictive value for job performance and learning speed, particularly in roles that involve problem-solving and decision-making. Standardized testing also allows employers to evaluate candidates using consistent criteria, reducing reliance on subjective impressions alone.
In large-scale recruitment, aptitude tests improve efficiency while helping employers identify candidates with the capacity to adapt, learn, and perform in complex environments. The focus is not solely on current ability, but on future potential.
What Aptitude Tests Do Not Measure
Despite their strengths, aptitude tests do not provide a complete picture of a candidate. They are not designed to measure motivation, work ethic, emotional intelligence, interpersonal style, values, or creativity in applied settings. They also do not assess job-specific knowledge or professional experience.
For this reason, aptitude tests are almost always used alongside interviews, experience reviews, and other assessment tools. Their role is to inform decisions, not to replace broader evaluation.
Preparation and Test Performance
While general cognitive ability is relatively stable, performance on aptitude tests is influenced by familiarity with question formats and testing conditions. Candidates who understand how these tests work and practice managing time pressure tend to perform more consistently and accurately.
Preparation does not alter underlying ability. Instead, it helps ensure that test conditions do not obscure a candidateâ€™s reasoning skills due to unfamiliarity or unnecessary stress.
You can start now â€“ try our free Cognitive AbilityÂ  Test .
Interpreting Results as a Candidate
Aptitude test results should be viewed as indicators rather than definitive judgments. They reflect performance under specific conditions, at a particular point in time. A single score does not capture the full range of an individualâ€™s abilities or long-term potential.
Candidates who understand what aptitude tests measureâ€”and what they do notâ€”are better equipped to approach them with perspective. This understanding allows for focused preparation, clearer expectations, and a more balanced interpretation of outcomes.
Understanding Aptitude Tests in Context
Aptitude tests are structured tools designed to reduce uncertainty in recruitment decisions. They are not intended to label candidates or to define professional capability in absolute terms. Instead, they provide employers with a standardized way to observe how individuals approach unfamiliar problems and reason under pressure.
For candidates, this perspective shifts the focus away from pass-or-fail thinking and toward preparation, method, and clarity of reasoning. An informed understanding of aptitude testing allows candidates to engage with the process on more equal terms â€” aware of what is being measured, why it matters, and how best to demonstrate their abilities within that framework.

Prepare to answer the most common interview questions
â€¢ Tell me about yourself
â€¢ Why are you a good fit for this job?
â€¢ What do you know about the role?
â€¢ What are your strengths and weaknesses?
â€¢ What would you do in your first month in this role?
â€¢ Why do you think we should hire you?
â€¢ Describe a situation you had to collaborate with a difficult client or customer
â€¢ Describe a situation where you made a mistake
â€¢ Describe a time when you received criticism
â€¢ Describe a situation where you went above the call of duty
â€¢ Describe a situation where you failed to meet a deadline
â€¢ Give an example of a time where you solved a customer problem
â€¢ Give an example of a time where you achieved a goal and how you reached it.
â€¢ Give an example of a time where you failed to meet the customerâ€™s expectations. How did you resolve this?
Research the company and position
â€¢ Learn about the companyMake a note of the companyâ€™s philosophy, values, and goals for the year as well as the next few years if they are publicly available. Most of this information can usually be found on the company web page. In addition, make sure you know the companyâ€™s history â€“ who founded it, when did they found it, what was their mission, how has the companyâ€™s mission changed?
â€¢ Get up to date with the companyâ€™s newsGoogle News allows you to get up to date on company news and press releases so make sure you check out the most recent happenings at the company. In addition, read their blog, and scan their social media for anything relevant to your role. Find something worth mentioning in your interview to demonstrate you truly understand what the company is doing now and try to find out why and how your role impacts their current mission.
â€¢ Learn the industry and the competitionIf youâ€™re moving into a new area, research the current challenges facing the industry and future challenges that they need to prepare for now. Find out who their biggest competitors are, look for any potential flaws or opportunities, and come equipped with an understanding of how your company fits into the industry as a whole. An awareness of this puts you well ahead of your competition and could secure you a place on their final shortlist.
â€¢ Know their products and servicesNothing impresses interviewers more than a candidate who has an extensive knowledge of the companyâ€™s products and services. What is their bestselling item and why? All you need to do is read through their products page, reviews page, and any public review pages or blogs. Do they cater to other businesses or do they sell to individuals? Do they work on big projects or work on a large quantity of smaller jobs?
â€¢ Prepare some intelligent questionsIf you normally struggle to find a relevant topic to ask questions about in the interview stage, then the best thing to do is ask a question in relation to the company. After completing company related research, prepare at least two or three questions to ask, as some things end up being covered in the interview, which could eliminate your prepared question if you only prepared one!
The power is in your hands
Try our free Quick Aptitude Test now .
Page 10/10: What Not to Do on Social Media When Job Searching - Aptitude-test.com
If you are in the process of applying for your dream job, youâ€™re probably wondering what you can do to maximize your chances of being offered the position. While youâ€™re busy polishing your resume, cover letter, and application, take a moment to consider your social media profiles. Social media platforms have given employers a greater depth of insight into potential hires than ever before. Here are 10 things to avoid doing on social media when job searching, so you know what you need to do to make a perfect first impression.
Manage your first impression A single job advertisement can potentially attract thousands of high-quality applications. While job seekers eagerly write and proofread their application and resume, they often fail to make sure their social media presence is professional, which can hinder their career in the long term.
â€¢ Using an unprofessional photoIf youâ€™re using an image of you at a party as your profile picture, then it might be worth considering whether you should change it. Think of it this way; the first photo your potential employer sees will cement a particular image of you in their mind. If you want to appear intelligent, confident, and mature, itâ€™s worth uploading content that reflects those qualities.
â€¢ Making spelling or grammatical mistakesJob seekers understand that itâ€™s essential to apply for a job with a resume completely free of errors. So why is it that so many applicants are happy to have an error-ridden social media profile? Most employers confess to quickly scanning social media accounts when going through the hiring process. If they see errors, they might question your ability as well as aptitude. Do yourself a favor and proofread everything you write.
â€¢ Getting into fights or troll peopleWhile you may think it is fun to get into disagreements with friends and strangers on social media, it doesnâ€™t make a good first impression. While you may think your behavior is hidden, you would be surprised to know how easy it is for potential employers to discover your comments. Do yourself a favor and keep any comments you wouldnâ€™t make in an interview off your social media platform.
â€¢ Sharing inappropriate contentAny form of inappropriate content, whether it relates to your work or not, marks you out as an unprofessional person who lacks good judgment. If youâ€™re thinking of sharing something, consider whether it is appropriate for the workplace or an interview situation.
â€¢ Talking badly about your employerIt doesnâ€™t matter how poorly your employer treated you; it is never okay to talk badly or negatively about your current or former employer. A potential employer will see this as a sign you may do this to them in the future, which marks you out as a risky hire.
â€¢ Uploading party photosItâ€™s never a good idea to upload questionable images to social media, especially when youâ€™re in the process of a job search. While you may think your fun photos portray you well, your potential employer may have other ideas. If you must share pictures, make sure you adjust your privacy settings so only your closest friends can view them.
â€¢ Getting too politicalItâ€™s probably not a good idea to get into a heated political debate on your social media account unless you plan on becoming a politician! You never really know what a potential employer thinks when it comes to politics. Instead of saying something that could put you in the companyâ€™s bad books, itâ€™s better to keep your opinions to yourself, as you would have to do in a professional role.
â€¢ Discussing your problemsSome people love sharing every single problem they have with the world, which is great in certain circumstances. However, it can backfire when youâ€™re on a job hunt. If you are too cynical, you may come across as someone they donâ€™t want to hire. Your potential employer might think youâ€™re someone who would bring a lot of drama to the team, which would make you hard to manage. Do yourself a favor and discuss your problems in person with your friends.
â€¢ Lying or using bad languageThereâ€™s nothing worse than a dishonest person, which is why itâ€™s so important to make sure you arenâ€™t unintentionally lying on your social media channels. If youâ€™ve listed your occupation, is it an accurate reflection of your title and work and does it match your resume? In addition, youâ€™ll need to make sure you arenâ€™t using any profanity, which can strike you off the list of candidates very quickly. As a rule, companies want candidates who represent them well in the public eye, which means bad language should have no place on your social media profile.
â€¢ Leaving social media or deleting everythingWhile you may think the answer is to temporarily remove your social media account or give social media a break from time to time, youâ€™d be wrong. Social media is the perfect way to boost your application with a professional-looking quality page that genuinely reflects who you are as an intelligent individual. Removing or deleting your page can make you look suspicious. Instead of looking as though you have something to hide, keep your social media and use it to showcase your strengths.
Social media as a strategy Instead of worrying, understand that social media can be effectively used to boost your application and increase the chances youâ€™ll be the companyâ€™s newest hire. While youâ€™re job hunting, ensure you act strategically. Audit and improve your online profile to showcase and enhance the skills, competencies, and experience listed in your job applications. When you actively broadcast such a great first impression, who wouldnâ€™t want you in their company?

Page 1/1: Aptitude Test: 16 Free Tests with 129+ Questions and Answers
Each test is free to take and includes questions, answers and fully explained solutions . After you take a test , write a comment below it to let others know how you found it.
Free Practice Aptitude Tests
FREE Numerical Reasoning Practice Test
FREE Verbal Reasoning Practice Test
FREE Inductive Reasoning Practice Test

FREE Logical Reasoning Practice Test
FREE Mechanical Reasoning Practice Test

FREE Situational Judgement Practice Test
FREE Spatial Reasoning Practice Test
FREE SHL Practice Reasoning Test
FREE Diagrammatic Reasoning Test
FREE Practice Critical Thinking Test
FREE This Practice Error Checking Test
FREE Practice In-Tray Exercise
What Are The Different Types Of Aptitude Assessments?
These are the most common types of aptitude test that you will encounter:
These tests require you to answer questions based on statistics, figures and charts.
A means of assessing your verbal logic and capacity to quickly digest information from passages of text.
A business-related scenario that assesses how well you can prioritise tasks.
Tests that measure your logical reasoning , usually under strict time conditions.
Psychological tests that assess your judgement in resolving work-based problems.
Tests that identify how well a candidate can see the underlying logic in patterns, rather than words or numbers.
A measurement of general intelligence, covering many categories of aptitude test .
These assess your ability to apply mechanical or engineering principles to problems; they are often used for technical roles.
Designed to assess a candidateâ€™s ability to critically consider arguments; often used by law firms.
Another name for inductive reasoning tests .
These tests assess your capacity to mentally manipulate images, and are often used in applications for jobs in design, engineering and architecture.
Error checking tests
An unusual type of aptitude test that focuses on your ability to identify errors in complex data sets.
How to Prepare for an Aptitude Test
Aptitude tests are designed to be challenging.
To ensure that you do as well as you possibly can, there really is no substitute for practice.
But donâ€™t waste time practicing more than you need to.
Find out exactly what type of aptitude test you will be taking and practice just this type of test .
First use example questions with explained answers to familiarise yourself with the types of questions you will be asked and then take practice tests to improve your performance.
What Are Aptitude Tests Like?
Aptitude tests are typically quite short, often less than 15 minutes long, and are usually completed online.
Tests generally have challenging time limits and often increase in difficulty throughout the test .
This is to put the candidate under pressure and try to understand what their maximum level of performance is.
Typically, tests present the candidate with some information and ask them to use this information to answer a question, usually providing a number of possible answers.
The more questions the candidate answers correctly within the time limit, the better their score will be.
While some aptitude tests will only focus on one type of thinking (either verbal or numerical reasoning , for example) some will have multiple sections that will test various different types of skills.
A multi-part assessment such as that will often take about an hour to complete.
Each section will be roughly 10 to 30 questions, depending on how complex each question is on a particular test .
Basically, if there are more complex questions, the assessment section will have fewer questions.
The position for which the test is being given may also determine the complexity and length of the assessment, i.e., the higher-level the job, the more questions and more complex questions are likely to be asked.
How Are Aptitude Tests Marked?
Aptitude tests are norm referenced.
This means that your performance on the test will be compared to a â€œnorm group.â€
A norm group is a group of people with similar characteristics to the candidate, a group of graduate trainees for example.
Your score will be compared to the scores of the people in the norm group, and this will allow the assessor to understand your performance relative to others who are similar to you.
Usually, a candidateâ€™s score is expressed as a percentile.
This, then, tells the assessor what percentage of the norm group their performance surpassed.
If a candidate scored on the 75th percentile, for example, they have performed better than 75 percent of the norm group.
Each particular employer may have a different performance level required for specific positions.
To be successful, the candidate must achieve a level of performance that exceeds a stated minimum.
Candidates will usually not know what the minimum score requirement is before they take an aptitude test .
Why Are Aptitude Tests Used?
Aptitude tests are often used by employers as part of a selection process for a job.
While aptitude tests wonâ€™t necessarily test candidates on their ability to perform a specific job within a company, they will give the employer a general sense of how well a candidate can think on their toes and demonstrate critical-thinking skills that would be reflective of the type of thinking theyâ€™ll need to do on the job.
Administering aptitude tests allows companies to narrow down the number of candidates who have applied for a job to a more refined group that may be more qualified for the job.
When Are Aptitude Tests Used?
Aptitude tests are most often used before a formal interview and are normally conducted online.
Employers often use the results of the tests in conjunction with how a candidate has performed in an interview to make a final hiring decision.
Combined, the two modes of assessment give employers a clearer picture of a candidateâ€™s ability.
How To Pass Aptitude Tests: Our Top 3 Tips
â€¢ Familiarize yourself with common types of questions that you will be asked. For example, numericaltestsoften have questions about percentages. Make sure you know how to work these out before yourtest!
â€¢ If youâ€™re taking anaptitude testonline make sure you are sitting somewhere quiet where you wonâ€™t be disturbed for the duration of thetest.
â€¢ When you are takingtests, work quickly but accurately and ensure you take a few seconds to double check youâ€™ve understood the question and that youâ€™ve actually selected the answer you had in mind.
Familiarize yourself with common types of questions that you will be asked. For example, numerical tests often have questions about percentages. Make sure you know how to work these out before your test !
If youâ€™re taking an aptitude test online make sure you are sitting somewhere quiet where you wonâ€™t be disturbed for the duration of the test .
When you are taking tests , work quickly but accurately and ensure you take a few seconds to double check youâ€™ve understood the question and that youâ€™ve actually selected the answer you had in mind.
THE JOBSEEKER'S GUIDE TO
The secret to not being intimidated by tests?
Test Structure for Aptitude Tests
Tests are timed and are typically multiple choice. It is not uncommon for some available answers to be deliberately misleading, so you must take care as you work through.
Some tests escalate in difficulty as they progress. Typically these tests are not designed to be finished by candidates.
Your score relates your performance to anaverage group.Your aptitude, ability or intelligence has a relative value to this average result.
Most employers take peopleâ€™s backgrounds into consideration for marking.
For example, maths graduates will have an unfair advantage over arts graduates on a numerical test .
Many aptitude tests incorporate negative marking. This means that for every answer you give incorrectly, a mark will be deducted from your total (rather than scoring no mark). If this is the case, you will normally be told beforehand.
In any test that does incorporate negative marking, you must not guess answers, even if you are under extreme time pressure, as you will undo your chances of passing.
Evidence suggests that some practice of similar aptitude tests may improve your performance in the real tests . Practice exam technique and try to become more familiar with the types of test you may face by completing practice questions.
Even basic word and number puzzles may help you become used to the comprehension and arithmetic aspects of some tests .
PREPARATION BEFORE THE TEST
Treat aptitude tests like an interview: get a good nightâ€™s sleep, plan your journey to the test site, and arrive on time and appropriately dressed. Listen to the instructions you are given and follow them precisely.
You will normally be given some paper on which to make rough workings. Often you can be asked to hand these in with the test , but typically they do not form part of the assessment
Donâ€™t get stuck on any particular question: should you have any problems, return to it at the end of the test . You should divide your time per question as accurately as you can â€“ typically this will be between 50 and 90 seconds per question.
Remember that multiple-choice options are often designed to mislead you, with incorrect choices including common mistakes that candidates make.
TIPS FOR SUCCESS
Thesefive tipsare well worth remembering before you take anaptitude testfor real:
Treat the test like you would any other exam.
Work swiftly and accurately through any test .
Work out the maximum time you can spend on any question and stick to it religiously. You can return to questions at the end. Never get stuck on any particular question, even if you think you nearly have it.
If you are going to an assessment centre, take a calculator you understand with you. If you do not, you will be forced to use whatever they might provide you with.
Answer as many questions as possible in the time given. But be wary of negative marking.

Page 1/10: Aptitude Test: 1000s Of Free Practice Aptitude Test Questions
What is an aptitude test?
An aptitude test is a way to measure a job candidateâ€™s cognitive abilities, work behaviours, or personality traits. Aptitude tests will examine your numeracy, logic and problem-solving skills, as well as how you deal with work situations. They are a proven method to assess employability skills.
Aptitude tests measure a range of skills such as numerical ability, language comprehension and logical reasoning.
What are the different types of aptitude tests?
There are a number of different types of aptitude test due to the range of cognitive capabilities and employer priorities. At Practice Aptitude Tests, we provide industry standard aptitude or psychometric tests for banking, accountancy, finance, law, engineering, business, marketing and vocational fields.
The most commonly used are numerical reasoning tests , verbal reasoning tests , diagrammatic reasoning tests , situational judgement tests , mechanical reasoning tests and personality tests .
Take a free practice aptitude test
Try a free practice aptitude test from the 16 test types below to prepare for your psychometric tests. All our assessments are written by accredited industry experts and are designed to replicate real exams used by leading employers.
Each has a strict time limit and at the end of the test you can view your score, benchmark and the full solutions to all the questions.
â€¢ Numerical ReasoningNumerical reasoning tests demonstrate your ability to deal with numbers quickly and accurately. These tests contain questions that assess your knowledge of ratios, percentages, number sequences, data interpretation, financial analysis and currency conversion30tests |480questions
â€¢ Verbal ReasoningVerbal reasoning tests assess your understanding and comprehension skills. You will be presented with a short passage of text which youâ€™ll be required to interpret before answering questions on. These are typically in the â€˜True, False, Cannot Sayâ€™ multiple choice format, although there are a range of alternatives too.30tests |450questions
â€¢ Situational JudgementSituational Judgement Tests assess how you approach situations encountered in the workplace. They are built around hypothetical scenarios to which you would be expected to react accordingly. Based on your answers it will be verified how aligned you are with values and behaviors of a particular company.50tests |480questions
â€¢ Diagrammatic ReasoningDiagrammatic reasoning tests assess your logical reasoning ability. The questions measure your ability to infer a set of rules from a flowchart or sequence of diagrams and then to apply those rules to a new situation.30tests |300questions
â€¢ Abstract ReasoningAbstract reasoning tests can also be referred to as diagrammatic and inductive reasoning tests. You will be expected to identify the relationships between shapes and figures, identify rules and similarities, and quickly apply these to establish the answer15tests |140questions
â€¢ Logical ReasoningLogical Reasoning tests come in three forms: deductive, inductive and abstract. These types of tests do not present you with verbal or numerical information, but instead with logical patterns and shape sequences.10tests |100questions
â€¢ Basic NumeracyMost job roles require a basic numerical skill set. This includes, but is not limited to, operational, customer service, administration, help desk and commercial.
Itâ€™s so easy to forget some of the basic numeracy principles that we once learnt. With this in mind we have put together this test pack to help you refresh your skills and improve your performance.15tests |300questions
â€¢ Analytical ReasoningAnalytical reasoning tests examine an individualâ€™s ability to apply logic to solve problems. The questions vary depending on the type of analytical reasoning test youâ€™re taking: anything from extracting key information from complex passages of text (verbal reasoning), to looking for patterns in a series of images (non-verbal reasoning), or using given information to draw conclusions or make predictions (inductive and deductive reasoning).44tests |538questions
â€¢ Cognitive AbilityCognitive ability tests are predictors of general intelligence. Like IQ tests, they examine your ability to solve problems and think logically, via verbal, numerical, mechanical, spatial and logical questions.35tests |456questions
â€¢ Spatial ReasoningSpatial reasoning tests your ability to think about objects in both two and three dimensions, and draw conclusions to those objects from limited information. These tests allow you to visualise two and three-dimensional images in your mind, and mentally manipulate these images into the shape that you want.10tests |100questions
â€¢ Mechanical ReasoningMechanical and electrical aptitude tests are commonly administered for engineering and technical positions including the emergency services and the army. They are designed to measure your ability to understand and apply mechanical concepts and principles in order to solve problems. These tests are usually multiple choice and under timed conditions. You will typically have no more than 40 seconds to complete each question.10tests |80questions
â€¢ Basic ComprehensionThese are foundation level verbal reasoning tests which assess your ability to reason using concepts wrapped in words. It verifies your level of understanding and comprehension, as well as your dexterity when it comes to filtering out key information from a bulk of text.15tests |225questions

Verbal reasoning tests assess your understanding and comprehension skills. You will be presented with a short passage of text which youâ€™ll be required to interpret before answering questions on. These are typically in the â€˜True, False, Cannot Sayâ€™ multiple choice format, although there are a range of alternatives too.
Situational Judgement Tests assess how you approach situations encountered in the workplace. They are built around hypothetical scenarios to which you would be expected to react accordingly. Based on your answers it will be verified how aligned you are with values and behaviors of a particular company.

The best way to prepare for aptitude tests is to practice them. The more you practice aptitude tests, the better youâ€™ll get and the higher results youâ€™ll achieve. You can start with these aptitude test sample questions and answers .

How are aptitude tests scored?
There are various scoring systems, but the two most common are raw score and comparative score. Raw score is when all your correct answers are summarized and displayed in percentage ratio. Comparative score is when your results are compared to the results of other people who took the test in your group.
What are aptitude tests used for?
Aptitude tests are used for the evaluation of a personâ€™s cognitive skills and character profile. They are increasingly used in recruitment to help hiring managers streamline their applicants. Itâ€™s the efficiency and accuracy of aptitude testing compared with hiring methods like interviewing that has made them so popular.
What do aptitude tests involve?
Aptitude tests assess a personâ€™s skills, abilities, professional attitude and personality traits. There are a whole range of aptitude tests and the challenges youâ€™ll face will depend on each. Theyâ€™ll involve a combination of numerical tests, verbal concepts, abstract thinking , field-specific reasoning problems (financial, mechanical etc), personality tests and others.
What do aptitude tests measure?
Aptitude tests measure a huge range of skills such as numerical aptitude, language comprehension and logical thinking . Different aptitude tests measure different aptitudes and employers specifically hand-pick aptitude tests to reveal the traits theyâ€™re looking for. Aptitude tests in the financial industry will be totally different to those in healthcare.
Why do employers use aptitude tests?
Employers use aptitude tests due to analyze a potential workerâ€™s profile. The test results are a strong predictor of how an employee will perform and fit in with the rest of the company. For instance, there are tests that estimate how well a potential hire will work in a team, or how strong their communication and problem-solving skills are.
Which employers use aptitude tests?
Aptitude tests are very common in the modern recruitment industry. Almost every big enterprise uses such tests as an additional tool for employee selection. Smaller companies often follow the practices of bigger business and are currently adopting aptitude tests as well. It is fair to assume that the majority of employers are using aptitude tests for HR purposes.
Why are aptitude tests so hard?
Aptitude tests are hard as theyâ€™re used to filter and differentiate candidates. By making them hard, assessors get a spread of results that provides a far more revealing view of test-takers. Some tests are made deliberately difficult to reveal how a potential hire performs under stress, or when facing unfamiliar information.
Where can I practice aptitude tests?
Youâ€™ll find many resources for practicing aptitude tests online. We suggest trying a handful to see which works for you. Feel free to begin with our full catalogue of psychometric tests â€“ theyâ€™re all written by accredited professionals. You can also use our fully worked solutions and interactive dashboards to help you improve.

The management associate programme, for example, is a leadership development programme, training future management candidates in teamwork and leadership. It gives a broad overview of the company as a whole.
Academy analysts have a highly tailored programme of business training that goes toward building the strongest base possible for starting your career with Citi.
With the full-time analyst programme, you will be trained to become one of Citiâ€™s analysts. This involves mentorship and detailed training, as well as hands-on experience dealing with clients and customers to set you on the right path.
The application process for Citi typically takes place over the course of a few weeks and consists of various stages. These include an online application form, some aptitude tests as well as a number of interviews, conducted either over the phone, in person, or via video call.

This test consists of a sequence of patterns that a candidate will have to analyse and interpret, to then relate to similar patterns. The group exercise is a chance to demonstrate your cooperation and communication skills. Teamwork is absolutely necessary and being able to problem-solve and reach conclusions as part of a cohesive unit will be tested at this stage.
You will be expected to work with a group of fellow candidates to complete your assigned tasks. Observers will be there to assess your communication skills, and the way you interact and operate in a group dynamic. As well as making suggestions of your own, be open to othersâ€™ ideas and opinions.

Page 3/10: Cubiks Test: Free Sample Practice Test Questions (2025)
Cubiks is an international assessment consultancy, with products used by businesses in over 50 countries for candidate selection, development and talent management. Cubiks tests are recognised as well balanced, easy to analyse, and straightforward for candidates to complete.
What is a Cubiks test?
Cubiks produces a range of online tests that can help with screening and selecting candidates, as well as identifying and developing existing talent. It is now part of PSI Services, and is the psychometric test provider of choice for many more big firms and smaller companies.
The Cubiks tests themselves can be broadly split into several categories (see below), and the questions relate to a specific skill set. Each question pack can be used separately, or a combination can be created that is specific to a particular career.
The Logiks tests are based on verbal reasoning, numerical reasoning and abstract reasoning, in either an Intermediate or Advanced test.
The PAPI (Personality And Preferences Index) is a questionnaire that is used to assess the way a candidate behaves at work.
The Situational Judgement Tests (SJTs) are used to assess a candidate for their skills in dealing with work situations, usually for leadership positions, and there are other tests available for assessing both candidates and personnel already in position.
The Logiks tests are intuitive and offer a simple interface for candidates, so they are easy to understand. Logiks tests are available as general assessments that include questions on verbal, numerical and abstract reasoning, at both Intermediate and Advanced levels.
The Logiks General (Intermediate) is split into three sections. The first is verbal, with 4 minutes to complete 24 questions. The numerical section should take 4 minutes, and there are 16 questions to answer. For the abstract section, there are 4 minutes to complete 10 questions.
The Logiks General (Advanced) has a similar structure to the Intermediate, with three distinct sections. In 20 minutes, the candidate must answer 12 verbal, 8 numerical and 10 abstract questions.
For the Advanced level questions, there are also three separate tests, each on a different skill.
As with other verbal reasoning tests , each Logiks verbal test presents a section of text that the candidate must read and understand. A question is asked about the content, and the candidate must answer based on the information provided.
No previous knowledge is needed or assumed, as all the information needed to correctly answer the question is provided. The answers given are multiple choice.
In the Logiks verbal test, there are 36 questions that must be answered in 25 minutes.

The PAPI (Personality and Preferences Index) is a personality questionnaire created to assess how a candidate behaves and performs in a working environment.
This allows the recruiter to understand more about the personality of the test taker and discover their strengths and weaknesses â€“ either to assess them against other candidates, or to provide a baseline for Continuous Professional Development.
The PAPI N (Personality and Preferences Index Normative) is usually used as part of a pre-employment screening process. The questions are presented as statements and the candidate must rate them according to how much they agree or disagree.
There are no right or wrong answers, so it is important that these questions are answered based on the way the candidate believes they behave at work.
As part of a recruitment process, the answers will be compared against a control group to highlight the candidates that are most suitable for the role in terms of personality and work preferences.
The PAPI N test is untimed, but usually takes 25â€“30 minutes to complete.
Answer : As this is a personality test, there is no correct answer.
The PAPI I (Personality and Preferences Index Ipsative) test assesses the candidates preferences and personality at work, using three statements about behaviour. These statements allow the candidates to select the ones that are most like and least like their personality at work.
In a similar way to the PAPI N test, there are no right or wrong answers. It is untimed, but usually takes 30â€“35 minutes to complete.
The PAPI I test results are not used to compare to others; instead, they are used to help form a development and training plan as part of the employeeâ€™s Continuous Professional Development.
Situational judgement tests assess a candidateâ€™s suitability for a role based on their decision-making skills. A work-based scenario is presented with several options for a suitable course of action; the candidate must choose what they would do in that particular situation.
In the Cubiks SJT, a brief description of a scenario is presented, along with possible actions. The candidate must select the next steps, based on their effectiveness at dealing with the situation in the best way.
For a candidate, this is a great way to demonstrate their problem-solving and leadership skills, as well as getting some insight into the role they are applying for.
The Cubiks SJT is a simply presented online assessment suitable for many roles in an organisation, from supervisory to upper management.
Answer : In the same way as the PAPI tests, the Cubiks SJT does not have a right or a wrong answer - it depends very much on your own problem-solving methods.
Which employers use Cubiks tests?
In the UK, the National Audit Office is an independent group that audits the government and parliamentary agencies. It uses the Cubiks test battery to assess candidates before interview, and as part of its graduate recruitment scheme.
Shell uses various Cubiks tests to screen candidates during the recruitment process as well as to develop employees in role. KPMG relies on Cubiks tests to help screen potential job candidates.

Because the Cubiks test batteries do not require any formal knowledge or training, there is no need to have extensive knowledge beforehand.
The day of your online Cubiks assessment, be sure to have had a good nightâ€™s sleep and a decent breakfast to set you up well for the test.
Find a quiet space where you are unlikely to be disturbed, and leave yourself plenty of time to complete the assessments in case there are any problems â€“ such as with your internet connection, for example.
Bear in mind that you are being assessed on your abilities, innate knowledge and personality during Cubiks tests.
How to pass Cubiks tests (5 key tips)
Although you might have taken similar tests in the past, practicing Cubiks assessments will help to make sure that you are as prepared as you can be on the day. 2. Make sure you are prepared
Alongside the preparation tips above, make sure that when you sit down to complete the test you have everything you need. This might include a notepad and pen, a calculator, or even just a drink.
Minimising distractions during the test will help keep you focused so you can perform at your best.
3. Read the information provided
There are no â€˜trickâ€™ questions in the Cubiks tests, and all the information you need to find the answers are available in the instructions and in the provided information. Take time to ensure that you read the instructions thoroughly, so that you can answer in the right way.
4. Be quick but do not rush
Some of the Cubiks tests, like the Logiks, are timed. You need to be aware of the time you are taking answering the questions â€“ so if one seems particularly tricky, leave it and come back to it at the end if you have time.
While working quickly through the Logiks questions is a good idea, you do need to be sure that you are giving yourself enough time to read and absorb the given information before answering.
5. Use the questions to help you
As previously mentioned, the information you need to answer correctly is provided â€“ you just need to find it. It might be in a table or graph as part of the numerical test, or written in a block of text on a verbal test, but it will be there.
Use the questions, statements and any other given information to help you throughout the process.

Prepare for your Cubiks Assessments
How are Cubiks tests scored?
Logiks tests are automatically given a percentile score based on total correct answers, speed and accuracy. These percentiles are created by measuring the scores against a comparison group that also took the test.
If your percentile score is 75%, this means that you scored higher than 75% of all the people that also took the test.
For the PAPI N test, your answers will be compared against other test takers as part of the pre-employment assessment. This means that the employer will use the answers you give to create a profile for you, based on your personality and preferences in a work situation.
In the PAPI I test, the answers are not usually compared against others. Instead, they are used to create a development and training plan.
Are Cubiks tests difficult?
Any psychometric assessment needs to be challenging for it to have value as a recruitment tool. The Cubiks tests are challenging because of their structure and the way in which information is presented, which is why practicing is important.
Once you have familiarised yourself with the structure and language used in the questions, it will be easier to focus on finding the right answers.
How long is a Cubiks test?
The Logiks General (Intermediate) test is just 12 minutes long, while the Advanced is 20 minutes long.
The Logiks Verbal (Advanced) and Numerical (Advanced) are 25 minutes long, while the Abstract (Advanced) is 15 minutes long.
The PAPI tests are untimed; however the PAPI N usually takes 25â€“30 minutes to complete and the PAPI I takes about 30â€“35 minutes.
How will I take my Cubiks test?
Most Cubiks tests are taken online, so they can be completed almost anywhere. For some employers, online assessments might happen at an assessment centre . A link to the test will be sent to you, for you to open and complete.
