70% of organisations reported improved hiring decisions and reduced recruitment costs by using psychometric assessments.
Why Top Leaders Choose Accendoâ€™s Psychometric Tools
Managing multiple assessments can be challenging. However, with an assessment marketplace on a single platform, such as TalentPulse, Accendoâ€™s talent intelligence platform, you can simplify and enhance the assessment process.
TalentPulse provides you with a psychometric test platform for the best behavioural assessment tools. By using the assessment marketplace within this platform, you gain access to the best psychometric tests for recruitment from various trusted psychometric test providers. They include:
AON assessments measure personality traits, attitudes, and psychological characteristics to gain insights into candidatesâ€™ behavioural preferences, motivations, and values.
â€¢ Personality Test (ADEPT-15)â€“ Measures a personâ€™s behavioural preferences, work styles, and tendencies across 15 personality aspects to gauge alignment with the competencies required for a job/role.
â€¢ Views (Work-Related Interests and Motives)â€“ Measures a personâ€™s motivation or drivers at work across 18 dimensions to gauge alignment with the cultural values of an organisation.
â€¢ Numerical Reasoningâ€“ Measures the ability to retrieve relevant numerical information, interpret and analyse to draw logical conclusions accurately under time pressure.
â€¢ Verbal Reasoningâ€“ Measures the ability to retrieve relevant verbal information, interpret and analyse to draw logical conclusions accurately under time pressure.
â€¢ Inductive Logical Reasoningâ€“ Measures the ability to identify patterns among information and make logical decisions by using bottom-up (inductive) logic to solve problems.
Hoganâ€™s assessments measure various aspects of personality, values, and motivations. It aims to provide insights into an individualâ€™s work style, leadership potential, and potential derailers that may impact job performance and career success.
â€¢ Hogan Personality Inventory (HPI)â€“ Measures the â€œbright sideâ€ of personality, offering insights into interpersonal style, work approach, and leadership potential.
â€¢ Hogan Development Survey (HDS)â€“ Measures the â€œdark sideâ€ of personality, identifying potential career derailers and disruptive behaviours under stress.
â€¢ Motives, Values, Preferences Inventory (MVPI)â€“ Measures an individualâ€™s values, interests, and motives, providing insights into their career aspirations, work preferences, and job satisfaction potential.
Formerly known as Revelian, Criteria assessments evaluate cognitive abilities such as problem-solving, critical thinking, decision-making, spatial reasoning, memory, and attention through Cognify.
Examples of Using Psychometric Tools in B2B/B2C Companies
Psychometric tools are widely utilised in both business-to-business (B2B) and business-to-consumer (B2C) companies to gather valuable insights about candidates and make informed decisions. Here are a few examples of how psychometric tools can be employed in these contexts:
Employee Selection and Recruitment
Psychometric tools can be used to identify individual strengths, development areas, and training needs within B2B and B2C companies. Assessments such as 360-degree feedback, personality assessments, or emotional intelligence tests can provide insights into employeesâ€™ abilities, preferences, and potential areas for growth.
Psychometric tools are essential in the hiring process for B2B and B2C companies. Assessments like cognitive ability tests, personality and behavioural assessments, and situational judgment tests provide objective insights into candidatesâ€™ suitability, helping predict job performance, identify desired qualities, and ensure fair evaluations.
Psychometric assessments can aid in performance management processes by providing objective data on employee competencies, strengths, and development areas. These tools can support performance appraisals, identify training needs, and align individual goals with organizational objectives.
Succession Planning and Leadership
Psychometric tools support succession planning and leadership development in B2B and B2C companies by evaluating potential, assessing competencies, and identifying high-potential employees. They enable informed decisions on leadership transitions, targeted development initiatives, and personalized feedback for aspiring leaders.
Team Restructuring and Reorganisation
When reorganising teams or merging departments, psychometric tools can help evaluate individual and team dynamics. These assessments can assist in determining compatibility, identifying potential conflicts, and facilitating smoother transitions during the restructuring process.
Organisations that use pre-employment assessments, including psychometric tools, experience a 40% improvement in new hire retention.
The Best Practices to Follow in Tool Selection
Now that we have seen the varying options of tools available, here are the three best practices that HR teams can follow in their tool selection process.
Identify what needs to be measured
To maximise the effectiveness of psychometric tools, HR teams should identify and assess key factors relevant to the role, such as logical processes, problem-solving skills, personality traits, integrity, and team fit. By aligning the tools with these criteria, HR can ensure greater relevance and accuracy in the assessments.
Customise and contextualise outputs
Psychometric tools are evolving to customise and contextualise results in familiar language for companies, enhancing output quality. HR teams must overcome the challenge of demonstrating the value of assessments to business managers using familiar terms, avoiding jargon. This boosts familiarity and adoption of psychometric tools within the business.
Consolidate when multiple tools are unavailable
In complex situations requiring the evaluation of diverse traits and skills, HR teams should seek psychometric tools that consolidate output. AI-driven platforms can aid in data interpretation, providing in-depth and non-conflicting insights, thus addressing the challenges of manual consolidation.
Assess reliability and validity
Thoroughly assessing the reliability and validity of psychometric tools ensures consistent and accurate measurements of psychological characteristics, providing confidence in the toolâ€™s ability to produce reliable results and accurately measure what it intends to measure.
Evaluate user-friendliness and accessibility
Considering the user-friendliness and accessibility of psychometric tools is crucial for seamless and effective implementation. Choosing tools that are easy to use and accessible to a wide range of users promotes a positive user experience and maximises the potential impact of assessments.
By familiarising yourself with our talent assessment tools, their selection criteria, and best practices for utilisation, you gain the ability to effectively use TalentPulse as a comprehensiveÂ solution catering to your assessment needs. This solution offers convenience, reliability, and improved outcomes throughout the talent management lifecycle.
To summarise our blog, here are the key takeaways:
â€¢ Psychometric assessments are widely used by 80% of Fortune 500 companies in the United States, indicating the value and benefits these tools bring to talent selection.
â€¢ Accendoâ€™s TalentPulse offers a comprehensive talent intelligence platform with an assessment marketplace, providing access to trusted psychometric assessments from top providers like AON, Hogan, and Criteria.
â€¢ TalentPulse simplifies and enhances the assessment process by consolidating multiple assessments within a single platform, eliminating the need to work with multiple assessment partners or vendors.
â€¢ Psychometric tools support various HR functions, including employee selection, development and training, performance management, succession planning, leadership development, and team restructuring, making them versatile and valuable across different organisational needs.
â€¢ The use of psychometric tools in hiring and recruitment processes leads to improved hiring decisions, reduced recruitment costs, and increased new hire retention, all of which contribute to a positive return on investment (ROI).
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)
What are psychometric tests in recruitment?
A psychometric test is used to assess a candidateâ€™s cognitive ability and personality . From a candidateâ€™s response, psychometric testing can predict valuable insights such as job performance, competence, and motivations. There are two general types of psychometric tests: ability tests and personality tests.
What does a psychometric test mostly does?
A psychometric test is an objective way to measure the potential ability of candidates to perform well in a job role . Psychometric tests measure a range of skills from cognitive abilities, knowledge to assessing your personality.
Are psychometric tools available on Accendoâ€™s Assessment Marketplace?
Yes, we have our psychometric tools on the platform as well as AONâ€™s; Cut-e & Adept tools, and Hoganâ€™s. Visit our assessment marketplace page to get more insights.
What are the 3 types of psychometric assessments?
The 3 types of psychometric tests are personality assessments, intelligence tests, and aptitude tests. Personality assessments measure traits and behaviours, while intelligence tests evaluate cognitive abilities. Aptitude tests assess specific skills in domains like numerical reasoning and logical reasoning.
Page 2/10: 6 Elements of an Effective Talent Acquisition Strategy | Accendo
6 Elements of an Effective Talent Acquisition Strategy
Talent acquisition is more than just a sophisticated way of recruiting. It is a strategic approach to identifying, attracting, and onboarding top talent to efficiently and effectively meet dynamic business needs. Learn more about how beneficial a talent acquisition strategy is to your company with these 6 key elements.
Experiencing a sudden and unexpected vacancy in a crucial role can put your organisation or the relevant department in a vulnerable position. This means that your recruitment team needs to take extra steps to find the best possible candidate right away.
What if you already have a pipeline of qualified candidates who are aligned with your organisationâ€™s mission and objectives? According to research, 65.7% of organisations say that building a talent pipeline is imperative for the future.
Applying the concept of talent acquisition can help you anticipate and prepare to fill the vacant roles. It can also help to create new roles as your organisation grows. In our previous article, we talked about talent acquisition, whether you should hire or acquire talent, and its best practices if you shifted from recruitment to talent acquisition.
In our article today, assuming you have moved over to talent acquisition, we will highlight the importance of a talent acquisition strategy, how these strategies differ for each type of company, and what are the elements needed to build an effective talent acquisition strategy.
Why is Talent Strategy Important?
By now, many are familiar with the Great Resignation in November 2021. More than 4.5 million employees resigned in the U.S., leaving employers to scramble in their efforts to fill the pivotal roles. Adopting a long-term focus and approach to talent sourcing and hiring can prevent your organisation from falling down the talent black hole.
Talent acquisition considers the potential employeeâ€™s possible career path in your organisation. It ensures you hire the right people who can eventually become future leaders. Without the right people, your business can struggle with low productivity, poor decision-making, and unmotivated employees. Here are six reasons why you should adopt a talent acquisition strategy.
How Talent Acquisition Strategies Differ for Each Company
Not all successful talent acquisition strategies use a â€œone size fits allâ€ approach. Planning and implementing will differ depending on several factors, including:
Top-tier organisations with thousands of employees, such as Microsoft, Google, or IBM, talent acquisition will likely be more of the growing and retaining of talent. That is because these organisations have a wider pool of talented individuals that is available for them to pick from.
Mid-level organisations with between 500 and 1,000 employees may not have the advantage of a wide talent pool of candidates or a huge war chest for salary and benefits. In such cases, a well-thought-out talent acquisition strategy could be formulated for two segments â€“ those that are well-known and those that are still brand new.
Small Companies and Start-ups
Smaller companies and startups may have limitations in their approaches when acquiring top-level talent as they often have to work on a limited budget. For instance, they could use freelancers or work with universities. They could also offer loyalty programs for employees or participate in various business development programs.
The 6 Elements of an Effective Talent Acquisition Strategy
Regardless of the size or scope of your business, talent acquisition must always be taken from a strategic approach. And scouting for top talent is easier when you have a great talent acquisition strategy in place.

â€¢ Recruiting databases: If you do not have a candidate database to pull from, consider partnering with a data provider who can provide access to a large quantity of talent.
The key is knowing where to look. For example, if you want to connect with product developers, you will have better luck on platforms like GitHub or Stack Overflow . While for sales and marketing talent, online job boards like Monster and LinkedIn will be a better fit.
Step 4: Nurture relationships and maintain communication
Once you have identified potential candidates, focus on building and nurturing relationships with them. Nurturing candidates requires a delicate balance on your part. You want to keep them interested, not irritate them.Â Instead of overwhelming them with job listings:
â€¢ Send them relevant, engaging content related to their interests or the conversations you had with them.
â€¢ Ask them questions about their own goals, experiences, and plans for the future.
Establishing trust and building a solid relationship early on can help make an impact when they start looking for a new role or accept an offer at your company.
Step 5: Provide development opportunities
Investing in your employeeâ€™s growth and development is key to creating a powerhouse talent pipeline as it provides opportunities for learning and development.
According to research, 70% of employees said that job-related training and development influenced their decision to stay at their job.
Various forms of training and development include:
Statistics also show that talent development programs yield several key benefits, such as: 87% of Millennials say that professional development and career growth are significant to them.
As you can see, talent development is critical to employee engagement and retention. By fostering a culture of continuous learning, you can cultivate a team of motivated individuals who are committed to growing and advancing within your company.
Step 6: Evaluate and measure the success of your talent pipeline
Are you concerned about whether your talent pipeline is working as it should? Evaluating and measuring the success of your candidate pipeline is vital to identify the areas for improvement while optimising your recruitment efforts.
Here are two ways of looking at it:
â€¢ Are your newly hired employees staying with your company longer?
â€¢ Is the performance of your employees meeting or exceeding expectations?
â€¢ These could be positive indicators that your talent pipeline is working well.
The impact of your candidate pipeline on your business goals:
â€¢ Are you able to fill key positions more quickly?
â€¢ Have you seen an improvement in employee engagement or productivity?
â€¢ Evaluating these metrics can help you to understand the ROI of your talent pipeline strategy.
7 Benefits of a Strong Talent Pipeline
To set yourself up for success, prioritise your candidate pipeline. Whether you are currently hiring or not, it is crucial to engage and nurture top candidates. Here are seven benefits of a talent pipeline:
Now that you understand the importance of having a well-crafted talent pipeline framework, and developing a strong talent pipeline strategy, are you ready to start building yours? Here are some key takeaways from our talent pipeline guide:
â€¢ Talent pipeline development involves creating a continuous stream of qualified candidates for present and future job openings.
â€¢ Building a robust talent pipeline requires defining candidate profiles, emphasising employer branding, proactive sourcing, nurturing passive candidates, and succession planning.
Want to know what are the top tools you need to develop a strong talent pipeline strategy? Stay tuned for our next blog on how to incorporate talent assessment solutions into your talent pipeline development so you can put your company at the forefront of the recruitment landscape.
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
What is talent pipeline management (TPM)?
Talent pipeline management is a systematic approach to identifying, nurturing, and managing a pool of talented individuals for current or future roles within an organisation. It involves strategies and processes to proactively attract, engage, and develop potential candidates to meet the organisationâ€™s talent needs. What is pipeline management in recruiting?
Pipeline management in recruiting involves effectively managing and engaging potential candidates to maintain a pool of qualified individuals for future openings. It includes relationship building, candidate engagement, and timely communication about opportunities, ensuring a steady supply of qualified candidates, reducing time-to-hire, and improving hiring quality. What is talent pipeline development framework?
A talent pipeline development framework is a structured approach that includes talent planning, sourcing, candidate engagement, and talent development to build and nurture a pool of potential candidates. It includes talent planning and forecasting, sourcing and attraction strategies, candidate engagement and relationship building, and talent development and retention initiatives. How can I measure the effectiveness of my talent pipeline?
The effectiveness of a talent pipeline can be measured through metrics like time-to-fill, quality of hires, offer acceptance rates, retention rates, and candidate satisfaction. Feedback from stakeholders provides additional insights. Regular assessment of these metrics helps optimize the talent pipeline and make data-driven decisions for improvement. What are some best practices for talent pipeline development?
Some best practices for talent pipeline development include proactive sourcing and attraction strategies, building relationships with potential candidates, creating a positive candidate experience, leveraging technology for candidate engagement and automation, aligning talent development programs with pipeline needs, and continuously assessing and refining the pipeline based on feedback and data. How can technology support talent pipeline development?
By integrating advanced talent assessment solutions into the process, companies can optimise their pipeline development strategies using applicant tracking systems (ATS), customer relationship management (CRM) adapted for candidate relationship management, data analytics tools, and online platforms, supports talent pipeline development by managing candidate data, automating processes, enabling personalised communication, providing insights into pipeline metrics, and aiding in sourcing and attracting candidates.
How can organisations ensure the sustainability of their talent pipeline?
To ensure talent pipeline sustainability, organisations should invest in talent development, implement succession planning, foster a supportive work culture, and adapt the pipeline to changing needs. This includes ongoing training, identifying high-potential individuals, creating an inclusive environment, and aligning with business goals.

Six Effective Talent Assessment Methods for Recruitment
When it comes to recruitment, implementing effective talent assessment methods is vital to identify the most qualified candidates. Let us dive deeper into the six categories of assessment methods.
1. Cognitive ability tests
These tests measure an individualâ€™s mental capabilities, such as logical reasoning, problem-solving, and numerical aptitude. They provide valuable insights into a candidateâ€™s ability to analyse information and make sound decisions.
2. Situational judgment tests

This method replicates real-life work situations, allowing candidates to showcase their skills and abilities in a practical setting. These assessments provide a glimpse into how candidates would perform on the job and help assess their suitability for specific roles.

Here are the reasons why using talent assessment tools will be advantageous to your organisation.
Selecting the right talent assessment tool is imperative for your HR teams to effectively evaluate candidates and optimise their talent processes. With a wide range of options available, it is important to follow best practices to ensure a successful tool selection.
1. Identify what needs to be measured

2. Customise and contextualise outputs

3. Consolidate when multiple tools are unavoidable

Conduct a pilot test of the tool on a smaller scale or for a limited time to evaluate its performance and ease of use to assess its functionality and suitability for your requirements. Pilot testing allows you to uncover any limitations, helping you make an informed decision about whether the tool is the right fit.
5. Assessments data interpretation

Look for tools that offer advanced analytics, data segmentation, and other relevant functionalities that align with your specific analytical needs.

What are the core elements of talent assessments?

Where are talent assessments used?
Some of the areas where talent assessments can be used are in talent acquisition, talent management, succession planning, HiPo identification, leadership development,Â and career pathing.
What is the difference between an assessment marketplace and an individual assessment provider?
An assessment marketplace operates as a single vendor for multiple tools with a single procurement process. While an individual assessment provider is a single vendor that carries individual assessments of different specialisations.
What is a talent assessment framework?
A talent assessment framework provides a comprehensive structure for conducting talent assessments. It outlines the key components to consider when assessing individuals, such as their knowledge, skills, abilities, personality traits, and growth potential. The framework helps organisations standardise their assessment processes and ensure consistency and fairness in evaluating talent across different roles and levels.
What are the talent assessment tools for succession planning?
Succession planning uses talent assessment tools such as competency-based, leadership, behavioural, performance, and development assessments. These tools identify potential successors, assess their readiness for higher-level roles based on competencies, behaviors, and past performance, and pinpoint development needs for targeted training.
What are the talent assessment tools for store managers?
Talent assessment tools for store managers include retail knowledge assessments, leadership evaluations, situational judgment tests, and behavioural assessments. These tools identify individuals with the right skills, leadership potential, and fit for the role. Role-play exercises may also be used to observe candidatesâ€™ performance in real-world scenarios.

Page 8/10: Introduction to the Test Development Cycle | Assessment Systems
Introduction to the Test Development Cycle
The test development cycle the process of building a high-quality assessment in accordance to international standards like NCCA or AERA/APA/NCME , so that it has validity . If there are stakes associated with the test, it is critical that the standards are met and the test is built well. Developing and maintaining a good test is not easy, and requires sophisticated work such as standard setting , job analysis , and item response theory .
Major Phases in the Test Development Cycle
So what are the steps of the test development cycle? Well, there is a well-defined and recognized process for, though it is rarely the exact same for every organization.Â  For example, the step of designing and blueprinting the test is quite different for certification vs. university admissions vs. K-12 benchmark , but you do need that step.
Even within the realm of certification, there is variation. Accreditation guidelines say you need to complete these steps, but leave the specific approach up to you.Â  For example, you are required to do a cutscore study, but you are allowed to choose Bookmark vs Angoff vs other method.
This article will provide a brief intro to major steps of the test development cycle. If you prefer a video walkthrough, hereâ€™s one of our YouTube videos:
Define the Construct and Target Market
The first step is to define what exactly the test is for, and how you want the scores to be interpreted. This is because validity, the most important concept in assessment, is the amount of evidence we have supporting the intended interpretations of test scores. So, obviously, we need to start off by saying what that is.
Itâ€™s also important to define the target market. Itâ€™s not just â€œmastery of fractions in mathâ€ but â€œmastery of fractions in the 4th grade math curriculum for Minnesota.â€ In certification, itâ€™s not just knowledge of ophthalmology; it is the level of knowledge needed to be minimally competent as an ophthalmic assistant.
Test Design: Job Analysis or Curriculum
A job analysis study provides the vehicle for defining the important job knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSA) that will later be translated into content on a certification or pre-employment exam. During a job analysis, important job KSAs are obtained by directly analyzing job performance of highly competent job incumbents or surveying subject-matter experts regarding important aspects of successful job performance. The job analysis generally serves as a fundamental source of evidence supporting the validity of scores for certification exams.
If the assessment is in K-12 education, there is typically a curriculum that the test is tied to, and therefore the design should be aligned. Admissions and placement testing require a plan based on the goal. Are you trying to predict success in technical undergraduate programs? If so, what are the abilities that maximize this?
Test Specifications and Blueprints
The results of the job analysis study are quantitatively converted into a blueprint for the certification test.Â  Basically, it comes down to this: if the experts say that a certain topic or skill is done quite often or is very critical, then it deserves more weight on the exam, right?Â  There are different ways to do this.Â  My favorite article on the topic is Raymond & Neustel, 2006 . Hereâ€™s a free tool to help . The image below shows an example of how to take the job task analysis survey ratings and turn them into blueprints.
For educational assessment, the process is not as straightforward, but still necessary. You might have a curriculum that clearly outlines the topics for an 8th grade math test. But how many items should come from each topic, and of what item type, and at what level of Bloomâ€™s taxonomy ? Youâ€™ll likely need a focus group of experts.
After important job KSAs and learning objectives are established, subject-matter experts write test items to assess them. The end result is the development of an item bank from which exam forms can be constructed. The quality of the item bank also supports test validity.Â  A key operational step is the development of an Item Writing Guide and holding an item writing workshop for the SMEs.
There should be evidence that each item in the bank actually measures the content that it is supposed to measure. In order to assess this, data must be gathered from samples of test-takers. After items are written, they are generally pilot tested by administering them to a sample of examinees in a low-stakes context. After pilot test data is obtained, a psychometric analysis of the test and test items can be performed. This analysis will yield statistics that indicate the degree to which the items measure the intended test content. Items that appear to be weak indicators of the test content generally are removed from the item bank or flagged for item review so they can be reviewed by subject matter experts for correctness and clarity.
Note that this is not always possible, and is one of the ways that different organizations diverge in how they approach exam development.
Standard setting also is a critical source of evidence supporting the validity of pass/fail decisions made based on test scores.Â  Standard setting is a process by which a passing score (or cutscore) is established; this is the point on the score scale that differentiates between examinees that are and are not deemed competent to perform the job.
In order to be valid, the cutscore cannot be arbitrarily defined. Two examples of arbitrary methods are the quota (setting the cut score to produce a certain percentage of passing scores) and the flat cutscore (such as 70% on all tests). Both of these approaches ignore the content and difficulty of the test.Â  Avoid these!
Instead, the cutscore must be based on one of several well-researched criterion-referenced methods from the psychometric literature.Â  There are two types of criterion-referenced standard-setting procedures (Cizek, 2006): examinee-centered and test-centered.
The most frequently used test-centered method is the Modified Angoff Method (Angoff, 1971) which requires a committee of subject matter experts (SMEs). Â Another commonly used approach is the Bookmark Method .
If the test has more than one form â€“ which is required by NCCA Standards and other guidelines â€“ they must be statistically equated.Â  If you use classical test theory, there are methods like Tucker or Levine.Â  If you use item response theory , you can either bake the equating into the item calibration process with software like Xcalibre , or use conversion methods like Stocking & Lord.
What does this process do?Â  Well, if this yearâ€™s certification exam had an average of 3 points higher than last years, how do you know if this yearâ€™s version was 3 points easier, or this yearâ€™s cohort was 3 points smarter, or a mixture of both? Equating determines this. Learn more here .
Psychometric Analysis & Reporting
This part is an absolutely critical step in the test development cycle.Â  You need to statistically analyze the results to flag any items that are not performing well, so you can replace or modify them.Â  This looks at statistics like item p-value (difficulty), item point biserial (discrimination), option/distractor analysis , and differential item functioning .Â  You should also look at overall test reliability/precision and other psychometric indices.Â  If you are accredited, you need to perform year-end reports and submit them to the governing body. Learn more about item and test analysis.
Test Development: Itâ€™s a Vicious Cycle
Now, consider the big picture: in most cases, an exam is not a one-and-done thing.Â  It is re-used, perhaps continually.Â  Often there are new versions released, perhaps based on updated blueprints or simply to swap out questions so that they donâ€™t get overexposed.Â  Thatâ€™s why this is better conceptualized as a test development cycle, like the circle shown above.Â  Often, major steps like Job Analysis are only done once every 5 years. Other steps like the rotation of item development, piloting, equating, and psychometric reporting might happen with each exam window (perhaps you do exams in December and May each year).
ASC has extensive expertise in managing this cycle for professional credentialing exams, as well as many other types of assessments. Get in touch with us to talk to one of our psychometricians.
Want to delve deeper? I recommend the aptly named Handbook of Test Development .
Nathan Thompson earned his PhD in Psychometrics from the University of Minnesota, with a focus on computerized adaptive testing. His undergraduate degree was from Luther College with a triple major of Mathematics, Psychology, and Latin. He is primarily interested in the use of AI and software automation to augment and replace the work done by psychometricians, which has provided extensive experience in software design and programming. Dr. Thompson has published over 100 journal articles and conference presentations, but his favorite remains https://scholarworks.umass.edu/pare/vol16/iss1/1/ .

Get in touch, and we'll meet to discuss how we can improve your exam development, delivery, and psychometrics!

What is Item Banking?
Item Banking refers to the development and management of a large pool of high-quality test questions. Items are treated as reusable objects, which allows you to more efficiently publish new test forms. Items are stored with extensive historical metadata to drive validity.
Then what? Well, once you publish test forms, you can immediately deliver on our integrated digital assessment platform, print to paper, or export the items for delivery elsewhere.
Your Partner in Smarter Assessment
Partner with industry-leading experts to ensure your testing program meets international standards and best practices.
Create item templates based on cognitive models developed by your subject matter experts. Define what is variable and what is held constant. Export for review before migration to your active item banking module.
Research has shown that automated item generation can drastically increase the size of your item bank, enhancing security. Research also found that it increases item quality (discrimination statistics) because item writers think more effectively about the structure of the item.
Best Practice in Workflow Management: Kanban Boards
Define the â€œswimlanesâ€ or columns/phases of your item review process.Â  Assign users to review items, based on custom review fields that you create.Â  Admins then manage items through the process, before being considered Live.Â  This ensures that only the highest quality items make it to the exam, and you have validity documentation of why.
The Kanban Board is regarded as one of the best approaches for project and task management.Â  It is used by most software designed for those topics outside the assessment field â€“ from Trello to Asana to JIRA â€“ with good reason.Â  This visual tracking of task progress and completion allows for more effective management, and our landmark platform allows you to apply this to the item banking process, driving team efficiency and item bank quality.
Users are shown a preview of the item, and all review fields that require their input, before they submit their assignment.Â  You can assign items ahead of time, and even send email notifications with due dates!
Items are not born perfect.Â  They almost always require some editing.Â  By ensuring that they go through stages of review, you provide a quality assurance pathway that enhances item quality.
Item banking is the foundation of the Test Development Cycle
Get in touch with one of our consultants to learn more.

Accreditation is the process of obtaining a stamp of approval that your certification exam is of good quality.Â  Anyone can write 50 questions in their basement and throw it up online, calling it a certification.Â  But there is much, much more to go through if you truly want a certification with validity.Â  Two of the most common boards are NCCA and ANSI .

â€¢ Classical test theory(CTT): This is a simpler approach, focusing on proportions and correlations, and regarded as essential for low-volume tests.

Page 1/10: Best Psychometric Software List, Reviews & Pricing in 2024 | SocialAtoZ
Psychometric Software helps give, score, and analyze psychometric tests. These tests measure mental traits, thinking skills, personality types, and how people tend to act. Companies often use this software when hiring, schools use it in education, and businesses use it to grow their teams. It gives them a peek into what people are good at, where they struggle, and if they fit well in certain jobs or tasks.
â€¢ Test Creation and Customization
â€¢ Automated Scoring and Analysis
â€¢ Psychometric Data Interpretation
â€¢ Reporting and Visualization
â€¢ Compliance and Validation
â€¢ Integration with HR Systems
Psychometric software gives organizations the tools to administer tests and obtain useful information about peopleâ€™s mental makeup. It helps with everything from making and administering tests to analyzing the results and writing reports.
To qualify for the Psychometric Software category, a product must:
â€¢ Give ways to make, give, and grade mental tests.
â€¢ Have parts that explain results, make reports, and follow the rules for mental tests.
â€¢ It lets users connect it to HR and other related computer systems.
The main benefit of psychometric software is that it can give correct and helpful views of people. This helps when making choices about hiring, growing skills, and placing students.
FAQs of Psychometric Software
What is a psychometric tool?
â€¢ Personality Assessmentsâ€“ These gauge traits, preferences, and behaviors.
â€¢ Intelligence Testsevaluate cognitive skills like verbal, mathematical, and spatial reasoning.
What are psychometric examples?
Well-known psychometric tests include:
â€¢ SATs and AP Examsâ€“ These measure skills and knowledge.
â€¢ Rorschach Inkblot Testâ€“ This assesses personality and behaviors.
â€¢ Myers-Briggsâ€“ This analyzes how people make decisions.
â€¢ Predictive Indexâ€“ This evaluates personality based on descriptors.
Can I create my own psychometric test?
Psychometric.com lets you build custom tests for specific skill sets. To make one, register for a business account and use the â€œCreate custom testâ€ section to design a test that meets your needs.
What exactly is psychometrics?
Psychometrics is a field of science that studies how to measure and link psychological traits, like intelligence, neuroticism, or depression, to observable data such as psychological test results, genetic profiles, or neuroscience information.
What does psychometry do?
Psychometrics measures psychological traits and brain functions, like intelligence or personality, scientifically.
Psychometry , by contrast, refers to a claimed supernatural power where people say they can learn details about a person, thing, or event by touching an object and sensing its past.

â€¢ Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) Solutions
Best Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) Solutions
Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) Solutions give developers a cloud-based setup to build, launch, and run apps without worrying about the complex backend stuff. PaaS solutions make app development easier by offering a bunch of tools and services that help create, roll out, and grow applications.
â€¢ Development Frameworks (support for different coding languages and development setups)
â€¢ App Hosting and Deployment
â€¢ Database Management (ready-to-use databases and data storage options)
â€¢ Middleware Services (built-in tools for communication and data handling)
â€¢ Scalability and Load Balancing
â€¢ Monitoring and Analytics
PaaS solutions let developers write code and create features without considering hardware or software setup. They help with many jobs, from making and testing apps to releasing them and making them bigger. These platforms give developers everything they need to build strong, growing apps.
To qualify for the PaaS Solutions category, a product must:
â€¢ Give developers tools and ways to work with different coding languages.
â€¢ Have ways to host apps, put them online, and handle databases.
â€¢ Offer choices to grow spread out work and check how well things run.
PaaS solutions are useful because they make building things easier and faster. This lets developers develop new ideas and get their apps out there. At the same time, the company providing the service takes care of all the behind-the-scenes stuff.
FAQs of Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) Solutions
What are the three types of PaaS?
Types of PaaS: Private, Public, and Hybrid
â€¢ Private PaaS: This type resembles a personal theater. You host it on your setup, which gives you full control over the settings and adds another level of protection.
What is PaaS in simple terms?
Platform as a Service (PaaS) offers a full cloud setting with everything developers need to create, operate, and oversee applications. This covers servers, operating systems, networks, storage, middleware, tools, and more.
What is PaaS Solutions vs SaaS?
PaaS (Platform as a Service) gives you access to a complete cloud platform to develop, run, maintain, and manage apps. The platform provider takes care of everything. SaaS (Software as a Service) lets you use ready-made, cloud-based software on demand.
Is Netflix an example of PaaS?
Netflix is a classic SaaS example. Users go to Netflixâ€™s website, pick a monthly plan they like, sign up, and start watching shows and movies right away.
What is platform as a service PaaS solution?
Platform as a Service (PaaS) gives you a full cloud setup to develop and deploy software. It has all the tools to build and deliver simple cloud apps or complex business software that uses the cloud.
Page 4/10: Best Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) Software List, Reviews & Pricing in 2024 | SocialAtoZ
â€¢ Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) Software
Best Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) Software
Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) is a suite of cloud services that enables the development, execution, and governance of integration flows connecting any combination of on-premises and cloud-based processes, Services, applications, and data can be shared and accessed within a single organization or across multiple organizations.
â€¢ Prebuilt Connectors and Integrations
â€¢ Application Development and Modernization
â€¢ Integration Flow Orchestration
â€¢ Third-Party Integration Management
Typically, an iPaaS tool provides prebuilt connectors, business rules, maps, and transformations that facilitate the development of applications and orchestrate integration flows. Certain iPaaS providers provide customized development kits to update older applications and enhance functionalities like mobile compatibility, integration with social media platforms, and management of business data.
Although IT departments have the capability to handle integration themselves, leveraging a third-party iPaaS provider can often be more efficient and economical. iPaaS providers can usually offer better integrations across more applications and environments than local developers can readily support. Using a provider also allows development staff to focus on other business software projects rather than integrations.
To qualify for the Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) category, a product must:
â€¢ Provide a suite of cloud services for developing, executing, and governing integration flows.
â€¢ Offer prebuilt connectors, business rules, maps, and transformations for application development and integration.
â€¢ Enable the orchestration of integration flows across on-premises and cloud-based processes, services, applications, and data.
â€¢ Offer custom development kits or capabilities for modernizing legacy applications and adding new functionalities.
â€¢ Facilitate third-party management of integration processes, freeing up internal development resources.
The core value proposition of iPaaS is to simplify and streamline the integration of disparate systems, applications, and data sources, both on-premises and in the cloud, through a centralized cloud platform that offers prebuilt connectors, orchestration tools, and the ability to modernize and extend existing applications, enabling organizations to focus on core business objectives while ensuring seamless integration across their technology landscapes.
FAQs of Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) Software
What is integration PaaS?
iPaaS, short for integration platform as a service, is a cloud-based solution that enables self-service integration of applications. It standardizes the integration process, making it easier to connect applications across both on-premises and cloud environments. iPaaS is also known as cloud integration or cloud-based integration.
What is an example of an iPaaS platform?
Ikea is a company leveraging iPaaS effectively. By utilizing SnapLogic, they have connected their different e-commerce systems and applications to their ERP system. This integration helps them manage inventory levels and customer orders more efficiently.
What is the difference between integration as a service and iPaaS?
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) differs from Integration as a Service (IaaS) and Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS). Unlike IaaS, where you get the infrastructure itself, iPaaS provides you with a platform to build and maintain integrations.
How can implementing an integration platform as a service iPaaS?
iPaaS ensures that data remains consistent across various sources and applications, allowing you to conduct real-time operations. For example, iPaaS enables syncing data from your marketing automation platform with your customer relationship management (CRM) and enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems.
What are three examples of IaaS?
Examples of IaaS providers include Rackspace, Amazon Web Services (AWS) Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2), Microsoft Azure, Google Compute Engine (GCE), and Joyent.

What is an AWS Partner?
An AWS Partner is a company or individual that collaborates with Amazon Web Services to provide services, solutions, or expertise to AWS customers.
How do I become an AWS Partner?
You can become an AWS Partner by meeting the requirements outlined by AWS and applying through the AWS Partner Network (APN) portal.

plain_text:
Page 1/1: Top 5 candidate assessment tools â€“ Psychometric Tests
As specialist users and explainers of all the major types of psychometric tests, from verbal and numerical reasoning to situational judgement and personality, we thought it made sense to apply that knowledge to the platforms that provide them. In this guide, weâ€™ve summarised some of the best psychometric test providers on the market, using our expertise and user feedback from sites like G2 and Capterra to highlight the pros and cons of each.
One of the biggest brands in psychometric testing, SHL is a global leader in talent assessment, offering a comprehensive suite of tools, including cognitive ability tests, personality questionnaires, and situational judgment tests. Their assessments are widely used across various industries to evaluate candidate potential and fit.
â€¢ Extensive range of validated assessments covering multiple competencies.
â€¢ Standardised testing promotes objective decision-making.
â€¢ Data-driven insights aid in informed talent management decisions.
â€¢ Users have said customisation of assessments can be complex, requiring a learning curve.
â€¢ Integration with existing HR systems may be challenging.
â€¢ Some users report concerns about data privacy and security.
â€¢ Pricing high for SMEs and smaller businesses.
Test Partnership is a UK-based provider of psychometric assessments, offering adaptive cognitive tests, gamified assessments, and personality questionnaires. Their assessments have strong predictive validity and a smooth candidate experience.
â€¢ Adaptive testing tailors difficulty to candidate ability.
â€¢ Strong predictive validity for job performance.
â€¢ Stronger science than most competitors.
â€¢ Test Partnershipâ€™s dynamic assessments are fully AI-resistant.
â€¢ Responsive customer support with access to trained psychologists.
â€¢ Limited public reviews or case-studies compared to larger competitors.
Sources: G2 , Test Partnership
Criteria offers a suite of assessments, including cognitive aptitude, personality, and skills tests, aimed at improving hiring decisions across various industries.
â€¢ Wide range of assessments covering multiple job roles.
â€¢ User-friendly platform with intuitive dashboards.
â€¢ Strong analytics and reporting features.
â€¢ Some users report occasional technical glitches.
â€¢ Pricing may be high for small businesses.
Sources: G2 , Capterra , Criteria Corp
ThriveMap offers realistic job previews and assessments to evaluate how candidates would perform in specific roles, focusing on cultural fit and day-to-day tasks.
â€¢ Customisable assessments tailored to company roles.
â€¢ Emphasis on cultural fit and real-world scenarios.
â€¢ Positive user feedback on improving hiring quality.
â€¢ May require more setup time to customise assessments.
â€¢ Less suitable for assessing technical skills.
Sources: G2 , Capterra , ThriveMap
Sova is a UK-based talent assessment platform that blends psychometric science with AI-driven analytics. It offers a suite of assessmentsâ€”including cognitive ability, personality, situational judgment, and video interviewsâ€”designed to streamline hiring processes and enhance decision-making accuracy.
â€¢ Comprehensive range of assessments covering various competencies.
â€¢ Customisable assessments tailored to specific job roles and organisational needs.
â€¢ User-friendly interface with intuitive dashboards and reporting tools.
â€¢ Strong emphasis on fairness and inclusivity in assessment design.
â€¢ Some users report a learning curve when customising assessments for niche roles.
â€¢ Integration with existing HR systems may require additional configuration.
â€¢ Limited public reviews compared to larger competitors, making benchmarking challenging.
Sources: G2 , Capterra , Sova
Final conclusions and recommendations
While the big names like SHL dominate in visibility, that doesnâ€™t always translate to the best fitâ€”especially for companies looking for modern, flexible solutions. Test Partnership stands out with its dynamic, AI-resistant assessments and strong predictive validity, offering a smart (and possibly better!) alternative to more traditional providers like SHL. If youâ€™re looking for something more immersive and focused on real-world fit, ThriveMap is another standout, especially for roles where day-in-the-life scenarios matter.

Page 1/10: Free Sample Psychometric Test Questions & Answers (2025)
Free Psychometric Test Sample Questions and Answers
Psychometric tests are a type of assessment commonly used during the hiring process. They explore the cognitive ability or personality characteristics of candidates, to measure their suitability for a role.
Psychometric tests come in many forms and styles, each measuring a specific skill or aptitude. They are broadly separated into two categories:
â€¢ Aptitude tests, which explore a candidateâ€™s reasoning orcognitive ability. Common aptitude tests include numerical reasoning, verbal reasoning, inductive reasoning and abstract reasoning.
â€¢ Personality tests: these assess a candidateâ€™s behaviours, drives, motivations and values to determine how well they fit the company and role.
As you typically do not need to learn any new information before taking a psychometric test, you canâ€™t â€˜reviseâ€™ for them as such. But practicing sample tests will help improve your scores by familiarising you with the format and style of the questions.
Have a go at our free sample psychometric questions below, and remember to check your answers with the solutions and explanations at the end of the page.
Sample numerical reasoning test question
What was the total value of Grade A and C wireless headphones produced in 2019?
â€¢ $490,000
â€¢ $540,000
â€¢ $550,000
â€¢ $790,000
Sample abstract reasoning test question
Which of the boxes comes next in the sequence?
Sample verbal reasoning test question
Statement: Therapists have some flexibility regarding what they deem serious enough to lead them to breach confidentiality.
Sample inductive reasoning test question
Which completes the sequence?
Sample spatial awareness test question
â€¢ Find the number of wireless headphones produced in 2019.
â€¢ Divide the number produced by 50 (the headphones are sold in batches of 50).
â€¢ Multiply this number (i.e. the number of batches) by the cost per batch.
â€¢ You need to do a separate calculation as each â€˜gradeâ€™ of headphone costs a different amount:
Grade A 2019 25,000 Ã· 50 x $500 $250,000
Grade C 2019 80,000 Ã· 50 x $150 $240,000
Total $250,000 + $240,000 $490,000
Solution: The circle is in the bottom-left every three turns, and the triangle is present in every two turns. Therefore, the box should not have a circle or triangle inside it.
Solution: In the last sentence, it mentions how â€˜individual employers and independent therapists have their own boundaries and must agree this contractually with their client at the outset of their therapeutic relationshipâ€™. Therefore, therapists do have some flexibility regarding what they deem serious enough to breach confidentiality.
Solution: The number of sides of each shape is decreasing by 2 each time you move along. The previous shape has 6 sides, so the missing shape must have 4 sides.
Solution: The large square overlays the small square with every two turns. The triangle moves from the top-left corner to the top-right corner with every turn. Therefore, there should be no large square, and the triangle should be in the top-right corner.
If you want to try a full free practice test for any of the above test types, click on the links below:
Alternatively, if youâ€™re looking for tips on how to do well in psychometric tests generally, check out our 10 tips to pass psychometric tests and 10 ways to prepare for a psychometric test .

Page 2/10: 10 Tips On How To Pass A Psychometric Test First Time
Psychometric tests are used in the recruiting process to assess the potential of a candidateâ€™s cognitive ability or fit within an organisation.
You may not have encountered a psychometric test before, or perhaps have not yet succeeded in getting a good enough result to progress. Either way, our tips for passing these tests should help you increase your scores.
Psychometric tests take various forms depending on the role and provider. Common test types include numerical reasoning , mechanical aptitude , logical reasoning and verbal reasoning . They are almost always taken online.
One of the key differences between aptitude tests and academic exams is that you are not being tested on your knowledge; rather how you think and react.
While you cannot â€˜reviseâ€™ as such because there is nothing to learn, there are lots of areas you can focus on to improve your chances of scoring highly when it matters. Weâ€™ve split our tips into two sections below: general advice, and tips for individual test types.
General psychometric test tips
1) Practise realistic online tests
Most psychometric tests are carried out online via your computer, so you should try to use practice tests that mimic those you will encounter (ie digital mock assessments are to be preferred over a book or ebook).
The various test providers also have different styles: some will ask you to interpret data and then select a multiple-choice answer; others might ask you to play an online game. Make sure youâ€™re familiar with all the test publishers (see tip 6).
2) Identify and work on your weakest areas
As you practice and get results, youâ€™ll be able to see which areas you tend to struggle with. Keep a note of the questions that you find hardest, and then practice more of those questions.
For example, you might find that you are struggling with verbal reasoning questions that have long paragraphs of text. Here, you could practice reading longer news articles at speed and then writing down all the salient points.
Many find numerical reasoning tests the most challenging; if thatâ€™s the case for you, check out our article on numerical test tips .
3) Get performance feedback
If you have taken psychometric tests before and didnâ€™t progress to the next application stage, donâ€™t forget to ask for feedback. It might be that you simply didnâ€™t carry out the test quickly enough, or didnâ€™t read the answers thoroughly and made poor assumptions.
All of these issues can be worked through with practice and preparation, but only if you know what the issues are.
4) Check all your technology is working well
Make sure that you are not hampered by a slow laptop or a poor internet connection. Also, ensure you know how to pause notifications and calls on your device, so that when you do take the tests you are not interrupted.
Have a back-up plan should, for example, your broadband not be working well on the day that you are due to take the test.
5) Broaden your knowledge and vocabulary
Particularly relevant for verbal reasoning , though it applies across the spectrum of tests. Spend time familiarising yourself with the skill of reading and understanding information that isnâ€™t in your normal sphere.
Read different newspapers and academic texts. This will help broaden your vocabulary, which can aid with quicker comprehension .
Once you have been invited to take a psychometric assessment for a specific company, try these tips to help you with your preparation.
6) Find out the tests the employer is likely to use
There are many different test providers with varying formats. The recruiter may specify which type of test provider they use, or you may be able to ascertain the information from their website. You can also consult our list of company tests for further details.
Once you have this information you can spend more time practising that specific style of test, so that you are familiar with the length and format, as well as the speed that you need to work through the questions.
7) Ascertain what the employer is looking for
Ensure youâ€™re confident as to what attributes the employer is seeking in their perfect candidate. You might be able to pick up clues in the job description â€“ for example, if the word â€˜ambitiousâ€™ is mentioned, they may favour employees with a behaviour profile weighted towards risk-taking.
You can also make enquiries with others who have gone through the process as to whether they have any advice to pass on. Check Student Room and Glassdoor, and ask among your peers.
8) Check what tools are allowed and know how to use them
Make sure that you are prepared in terms of the rules of the test. Some tests let you use a calculator; for those, have one to hand and know how to work any relevant functions.
For any maths-based test where you arenâ€™t allowed one, have paper and pencil to hand, and learn how to calculate basic functions such as adding percentages .
9) Check the timings and know when you need to move on
Most psychometric tests are timed, and this is usually taken into account when assessing each candidate. Remember that each question is either right or wrong (there are no marks for the way you achieve each question). As such, sometimes youâ€™ll need to prioritise time taken over getting the correct answer.
You may find that you are provided with a rough time guide and a suggestion of how many questions will be asked. If so, calculate how long you have per question and stick to it.
10) Donâ€™t rush reading the data for each question
That said, ensure that you have actually understood what each question is asking you without leaping to assumptions. It can be easy to select the wrong answer too quickly, particularly in the kind of question that is designed to catch you out.

Page 4/10: 10 Most Common Psychometric Test Mistakes (What To Avoid)
Psychometric tests â€“ such as numerical reasoning tests , verbal reasoning tests and logical reasoning tests â€“ are commonly used by employers in the early stages of the recruitment process. These challenging assessments help to indicate which candidates in the cohort possess the mental agility to perform well under pressure.
Achieving the best results possible is important as, in a competitive job market, often only the top 10% of candidates progress to the next stage of the application process.
The question types and overall test structure will vary according to which psychometric test you are required to sit, but there are preparation factors that apply across all psychometric test types .
To ensure you are adequately prepared and perform to the highest standard come the day of your test, consider our list of the ten most common mistakes below and how to avoid them.
1) Inadequate question practice
Aptitude test questions can be tricky without preparation. The questions often contain superfluous information or answer options that are intentionally misleading.
Adequate practice with mock psychometric test questions will help improve both your confidence and ability.
2) Lack of research on test type and publisher
Not all psychometric tests are created equal, as their demands vary according to the publisher. For example, while most psychometric tests have challenging time limits, Cappfinity tests have no time restriction.
Seek to find out as much as you can about the aptitude test you will be sitting, so you can tailor your practice accordingly and use the most accurate material. If test type or publisher information is not initially given, enquire with your prospective employer.
Practice Aptitude Tests has psychometric test questions organised by test type , industry , employer and publisher , to help with targeted preparation.
3) Not sticking to timings when taking the test
To secure a top test score, you must answer accurately and rapidly. Take heed of the timings you will be faced with and practice to the same time limit, so you become used to the pace required to complete the test.
It may be tempting to spend longer on questions you find tricky, but it is unwise to exceed the time allotted. For example, if you are sitting an SHL numerical reasoning test and have 20 minutes to answer 20 questions, keep to 1 minute per question. Once the minute is up, select an answer and move straight on to the next question.
You can always return to review questions at the end if you have time. If you intend to come back to a question, note down its number for ease of reference later.
4) Getting others to help you during the test
Initial stage psychometric assessments are most often taken online at home. This means the tests are not policed, so technically there is scope for candidates to enlist assistance from friends or family.
This is foolish on two fronts. Psychometric tests are often taken under timed conditions, so there is little time to consult with others or become distracted from your thought process. Working in this way you will likely not answer enough questions to pass the assessment.
Employers also commonly require psychometric tests to be retaken at a later stage in the recruitment process to verify your scores.
Trust in your own ability and prepare properly.
5) Getting insufficient sleep the night before the test
Psychometric tests require clear, logical thinking and rapid problem solving. With lack of sleep, your brain will not be able to function to the best of its ability.
As achieving the highest score possible gives you the best chance of moving to the next stage in the recruitment process, ensure you get at least eight hours of sleep. It is also wise â€“ if you are taking the test at home and can choose when you complete it â€“ to sit your test at the time of day you feel most refreshed and alert.
6) Not reading the questions properly before answering
Whilst you will likely need to stick to a fast pace to complete the test in the allotted time, you must not rush. Racing through the test, without paying attention to the detail, will not result in accurate answers.
Psychometric test questions often contain distractors, which are pieces of information that are irrelevant and included to mislead. Approaching each question calmly, having read and processed the information given to identify the salient parts, is the best way to reach the correct answer.
7) Failing to focus your revision time on your weakest areas
When preparing to sit your psychometric test, it is important to practice with question material similar to the real assessment and then to take the time to review your results. Looking over your practice tests will help you to identify your strengths and weaknesses, and track your progress across different topic areas.
Although it is tempting to revise topics in which you are more confident and can achieve a good confidence-boosting score, to perform well overall you will need to spend time focusing upon building your ability in your weakest areas.
8) Failing to read the test instructions carefully
Do not assume you know the exact format of the test because you have taken multiple practice tests, as assessment styles can vary according to publisher (and even between iterations of test material produced by the same provider).
Check the time allocated for the test and the number of questions included are as expected (and make any adjustments to pace necessary if they are not). Read through the instructions for each section of the test, paying close attention to how your answers should be logged.
The instructions may also contain handy tips or even an example question. Ensure you take the help provided to you by reading all available information.
9) Not having the correct materials for the test
Whether you are sitting the test at home or at a test centre, it will likely be up to you to ensure you have the materials you need to sit the test. For example if you are sitting a numerical reasoning test, make sure you have a scientific calculator that can perform all the functions you may require.
You do not have to hold all the information in your head when answering questions, as you can use rough paper and a pencil to jot down any workings. It is easy to overlook this aid when completing digitised tests.
As the tests are administered online, if you are taking the test at home you will need a computer with a recently updated browser and a stable internet connection. This will allow the assessment questions to load smoothly and avoid any technical issues.
10) Not reviewing multiple-choice answer options
Multiple-choice answers are a common feature of most psychometric tests. The best method of approaching them depends on the type of test and your personal preference but, as a general rule, it is better to start with the question and work to the answer rather than working backwards from several answers.
While itâ€™s not wise to dwell upon each potential answer before beginning your own independent thought process, glancing at the potential answers before starting to solve the problem is sensible. If you have an awareness of the answer list, it will help you to quickly judge if your workings are leading you in the right direction.

Page 6/10: Numerical Reasoning Test: 100s Of Free Practice Tests (2025)
Numerical reasoning tests demonstrate your ability to deal with numbers quickly and accurately. These tests contain questions that assess your knowledge of ratios, percentages, number sequences, data interpretation, financial analysis and currency conversion.
What Is a Numerical Reasoning Test?
A numerical reasoning test is a psychometric assessment that measures how well a candidate interprets and analyzes numerical data. Unlike traditional math exams, these tests evaluate how you apply mathematical logic to real-world scenarios, often under time pressure.
Youâ€™ll typically work with:
â€¢ Charts, tables, and graphs
â€¢ Financial and statistical data
â€¢ Word problems with quantitative reasoning
Candidates are required to perform calculations involving:
â€¢ Ratios and proportions
â€¢ Fractions and decimals
These tests are less about memorizing formulas and more about applying mathematical understanding in business contexts.
Why Do Employers Use Numerical Reasoning Tests?
Employers use numerical reasoning tests to screen candidates for:
â€¢ Analytical and critical thinking skills
â€¢ Accuracy under time constraints
â€¢ Decision-making with incomplete or complex data
â€¢ Quantitative aptitude relevant to the role
These tests are commonly used in:
â€¢ Finance and bankingâ€“ for investment analysts, accountants, and traders
â€¢ Consultingâ€“ for strategy, operations, and performance roles
â€¢ Engineering and techâ€“ for roles involving modeling and data-driven design
â€¢ Graduate programsâ€“ to fairly compare large applicant pools
By using numerical reasoning assessments, employers standardize the early stages of recruitment and gain data-driven insights into candidate performance.
What to Expect in a Numerical Reasoning Test
Numerical reasoning tests vary by provider, but most include:
â€¢ Timed assessments (typically 20â€“40 minutes)
â€¢ Business-themed scenarios using real-world data
â€¢ Data interpretation: Analyzing tables, line graphs, or pie charts
â€¢ Profit/loss problems: Calculating margins, percentages, or trends
â€¢ Word problems: Applying numerical reasoning to case-based scenarios
â€¢ Time-based math: Scheduling, logistics, or productivity challenges
â€¢ SHL: Offers assessments focusing on data interpretation and numerical analysis.
â€¢ Talent Q: Features adaptive tests that adjust in difficulty based on the candidateâ€™s responses.
â€¢ Cubiks: Provides tests emphasizing speed and accuracy in numerical computations.
â€¢ Kenexa: Known for tests that assess numerical reasoning in business contexts.

Numerical Reasoning Tests Tips
If taking your test at an assessment centre, make sure you know exactly where youâ€™re going, and arrive early to avoid panic. If taking your test online, make sure youâ€™ll have no interruptions, and double-check your internet connection for stability.
2Digest the practice questions in the real test
Most numerical reasoning tests start with a couple of practice questions to get you warmed up. Study these carefully and make note of structure, content and style. Theyâ€™ll give you a good indication of whatâ€™s to come and get you in the right frame of mind.
3Pay close attention to detail
The easiest way to slip up on your test is to misinterpret the question. You may be working against the clock but donâ€™t let that stop you from taking the time to understand what is being asked. Read each question carefully to avoid silly mistakes.
4Work with what you've been given
Each question will include all the information you need to draw the right conclusion, so donâ€™t make assumptions about the data. Just work with whatâ€™s in front of you.
5Don't dwell on difficult questions
Remember, youâ€™re working on a time limit, so if you find yourself stuck, move on. Often, the more you struggle with a complex problem, the more confused you become. You can always come back for another go if you have time to spare at the end.
6Take an educated guess
Where you are unsure of the answer, use a process of elimination to narrow down your options. An unanswered question will score you nothing. An educated guess may well prove correct.
7Beware of red herrings
As mentioned, multiple-choice options in numerical reasoning tests can often include distractors, and questions can include irrelevant information designed to put you off track. Keep your wits about you, double-check your answers for accuracy, and focus only on the information you need.
8Double-check what you're working with
Some questions may require you to work with varying units of measurement, multiple currencies, or different number representations. Make sure youâ€™re using the right information in the right way to draw your conclusions.
Although itâ€™s important not to let it become a distraction, you need to be aware of timing. As a rule of thumb, one question every minute is a steady pace, though some tests will allow more, and some less. Practice is essential here, so be sure to include pacing as part of your test preparation.
10Stay calm and focused
Numerical reasoning tests require fixed concentration, so shut yourself off from whatever surrounds you. Though itâ€™s easier said than done for some, try not to let the pressure get to you, and keep a cool head thatâ€™s zoned in on the task at hand.

Numerical Reasoning Tests FAQs
How are numerical reasoning tests scored?
Numerical reasoning tests use various scoring systems, but the two most common are raw and comparative. Raw score is when all your correct answers are summarized and displayed in percentage ratio. Comparative score is when your results are compared to the results of other people who took the test in your group.
Where will I take my numerical reasoning test?
Depending on the employer, you may be asked to take your numerical reasoning test online, or in person at an assessment centre. If online, it may also be the case that youâ€™re required to sit a second test in person as an anti-cheat precaution.
When should I expect my results?
Unfortunately, thereâ€™s no answer to this. It will vary between employers. If youâ€™re unsuccessful in progressing to the next stage, you may not even receive your results at all. Where this is the case, you can always try contacting the HR department for feedback on your assessment. This can help you improve in future tests.
What's more important â€“Â speed or accuracy?
Ideally you want a fine balance between the two. The more questions you answer, the higher your score, but only if you get them right. Donâ€™t take chances, and donâ€™t let the time pressure get to you. Ultimately, practice is more important than either, since this is the best way to ensure you can work both quickly and correctly.
Can you use a calculator in numerical reasoning tests?
In most cases, yes, youâ€™ll be able to use a calculator, and we recommend using one that youâ€™re familiar with. However, this might not always be possible. There are some numerical assessment tests that donâ€™t allow them at all, and others where, if taking the test in person, youâ€™ll be given a standard issue calculator at the assessment centre. Every test will have different rules, so if you can, check this information beforehand.
Why are numerical reasoning tests so hard?
Numerical reasoning tests are hard to ensure that thereâ€™s a nice spread of results for employers to gain a strong understanding of their candidatesâ€™ analytical abilities. On top of this, some numerical reasoning tests are purposefully written to be difficult to reveal how candidates perform under pressure.
Where can I practice numerical reasoning tests?

Page 7/10: How to Add Consecutive Percentages Together - Full Guide
How to add percentages together:
â€¢ Add the given percentages to 100.
â€¢ Convert the percentages to decimals.
â€¢ Multiply to the base value.
â€¢ Multiply the second percentage.
Weâ€™ll go through these stages in detail below.
Step 1: Add the given percentages to 100
For example, if we want to increase 300 by 10% then increase the result by 20%.
Step 2: Convert the percentages to decimals
Change the percentages to decimal by moving two decimal places to the left of the percentages.
Step 3: Multiply to the base value
Multiply the first given percentage (in decimal form) to the base value. So, for our example, we multiply 300 by 1.10.
Step 4: Multiply the second percentage
Use the new value and multiply the second percentage (also in decimal form). To find the final value, we multiply 330 by 1.20.
Examples of adding consecutive percentages together:
Q1) A store sells a pair of pants at a profit of 15%. A concessionaire also adds 5% on top of the cost. If the supplier cost of the pants is $800, how much would a customer have to pay at a concessionaire?

Move the percentages two decimal places to the left.
Now that we have the decimal forms, we first multiply 800 by 1.15.
To find the final cost, we multiply 920 by 1.05.
So, the final cost of the pants would be $966 at the concessionaire.
